Title: Contribution of Small-Scale Gum and Resin Commercialization to Local Livelihood and Rural Economic Development in the Drylands of Eastern Africa
Author_affil: Institute of International Forestry and Forest Products, Technische Universití€Œ_t Dresden
Funding: Erasmus Mundus (EMJDP) within the framework of Forest and Nature for Society (FONASO) programme; German Research Foundation and the Open Access Publication Funds of the TU Dresden
Stated_int: NTFP commercialization
Desired_out: Gum arabic, frankincense, myrrh, and oppopanex are economically viable commercial NTFPs and represent important sources of livelihoods of local community, employment, & foreign exchange earnings. Consumed locally as traditional medicines, foods, and beverages, and are used in religious and cultural rituals.
Study_goal: The study was motivated by the following research questions: (i) To what extent does the economic gain derived from the small-scale production of natural gum and resins impact rural livelihood improvement and poverty alleviation? (ii) What factors explain the inter-household and regional (inter-case) variations in the level of income and dependence on gum and resin incomes? (iii) What lessons and recommendations can be drawn to promote rural economic development based on commercialization of high value NTFPs in the dryland regions of Ethiopia and Sudan?
Study_location: Central Sudan, North Kordofan 12í‰ŒÁ27í¢ä‰åŒ_í¢ä‰åäóì13í‰ŒÁ15í¢ä‰åŒ_ N 28í‰ŒÁ15í¢ä‰åŒ_í¢ä‰åäóì29í‰ŒÁ55í¢ä‰åŒ_ E, Villages of Direra, Helet Ismeal in Elnehud; Central Sudan, North Kordofan 12í‰ŒÁ30'í¢ä‰åäóì14í‰ŒÁ15' N 30í‰ŒÁ20'í¢ä‰åäóì32í‰ŒÁ30' E, villages of Amanallah, Elmerhabiba in Ummrawaba; North Ethiopia, Tigray Region 13í‰ŒÁ10'í¢ä‰åäóì13í‰ŒÁ35' N 38í‰ŒÁ35'í¢ä‰åäóì39í‰ŒÁ05' E, villages of Tseykeme, Tarma in Abergelle; South Ethiopia, Oromya Region 4í‰ŒÁ05'í¢ä‰åäóì4í‰ŒÁ25' N 38í‰ŒÁ39'í¢ä‰åäóì38í‰ŒÁ56' E, villages of Dhass, Wolensu in Borena
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with planted trees, trees on farms, or tree farms
Comps_notes: Also separated by access to and management of resource (private/public managed locally & open access)
Stated_outcomes: Contribution of gum & resin income to household economy, level of engagement & experience with gum/resin production, absolute & relative gum & resin income across income quartiles, expenditure of income from gum & resin, seasonality of income, role of income in poverty mitigation and reducing income inequality, determinants of income
Portion_livelihood_amount: Gum and resin production and collection represent an integral part of householdsí¢ä‰åä‹¢ livelihood sources in the study areas. These NTFPs generate considerable cash income contributing to 21%, 14%, 20% and 23% of the total household income in Ummrawaba, Elnehud, Abergelle and Borena, respectively (Figure 2). The income variation basically corresponds to the gradient of the resource management, increasing from open-access wild resource (in Borena) to regulated access natural woodland (Abergelle) and to intensively managed gum gardens on private lands (Ummrawaba and Elnehud).

Title: Poverty, property rights and collective action: understanding the distributive aspects of common property resource management
Author_affil: Environment Department, The University of York, Heslington, York YO10 5DD, United Kingdom
Funding: The research received generous financial support from the South Asian Network for Development and Environmental Economics (SANDEE).
Stated_int: Common property resource management - community forestry
Desired_out: Economic development, sustainable resource use, improved livelihoods
Int_dur: The last two decades (from publication time)
Study_goal: This paper examines this broad concern by investigating whether recent policy shifts (institutional change) towards community forest (CF) resource management in Nepal have increased access of poorer households to the resources.The working hypotheses of the paper are: (1) the poor are, in absolute terms, less dependent, but, in relative terms, more dependent than the ïless poorÍ on forest resources; (2) there are differential impacts of CF management and the poor benefits less than the rich or ïless poorÍ; and (3) ability to use the CF resources is directly linked to heterogeneity in private resource endowments of households.
Study_location: Kavre Palanchok and Sindhu Palanchowk districts in the mid-hills of Nepal.
Study_duration: The Survey was conducted for a period of four months from September to December 2000. The main fieldwork was supplemented by two short visits, September_October 2001 (by two research assistants) and February 2002 (PI), to clarify various concerns raised during the main survey..
Portion_livelihood_amount: See Tables 4 and 7 of paper.

Authors: Agrawal A, Gupta K

outcome.Indicators: Likelihood of participation in user groups formed through the PPP
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: Results from statistical analysis are presented starting on page 1106. There are a number of statistically significant determinants of participation. Two of the three economic variables„ income and land„are statistically significant. Households with supplementary income in addition to their income from agriculture are more likely to participate in user groups created by the PPP (coefficient = 0.477, significant at the 10% level). Similarly, households that own more land are more likely to participate to a greater extent in the groups created by the program (coefficient = 0.004, significant at the 5% level). Both the social variables are statistically significant. The high statistical significance of the caste variable confirms the hypothesis that lower-caste members participate relatively less in the user groups created by the PPP (coefficient = 0.554, significant at the 1% level). The education variable has a negative sign and is statistically significant (coefficient = -0.012, significant at the 5% level). This indicates that the higher the average number of years of education of the adult members in a household, the lower the likelihood of the household participating in the program.Of the two variables related to benefits from the resource (firewood and fodder), firewood is statistically significant. This means that as anticipated, households that use higher amounts of firewood from the forest are also more likely to try to participate in the program and to influence decision making in local groups through participation (coefficient = 0.1, statistically significant at the 5% level). Other variables are discussed in this section.

Authors: Alix-Garcia J, Aronson G, Radeloff V, Ramirez-Reyes C, Shapiro E, Sims K, Ya_ez-Pagans P

outcome.Indicators: Average impacts of PSAH on consumption: food, durables, housing; Average impacts of PSAH on productive (agricultural) and educational investment
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: Impacts on wealth: slightly positive in all cases but not statistically significant and not different across private vs. communal households; For productive investment impacts: "In the common properties, we observe a positive and marginally significant increase in the number of cattle (0.9 more per household) and a positive but not significant increase in the 46 number of small animals (2.5 more). We do not see sizeable or significant changes in the likelihood of investing in livestock infrastructure, agricultural inputs or agricultural equipment. However, we do observe a fairly large increase (around 15 percent relative to baseline) in the probability of attending school for children between the ages of 15 and 17 years old. We also see positive but insignificant increases in school attendance for children between 12-14 years old and 18-22 years old. In general, we do not see significant variation between common property ejidatarios and non-ejidatarios, although the marginal increase in cattle is significant and sizeable for beneficiary households (1.2 more, relative to the base mean of 3.5). There are no significant impacts for private households, although the coefficient on schooling implies a 10 percent increase relative to baseline in the probability of attending school for students between 12-22 years."

outcome.Indicators: Application, transportation and implementation costs
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: Application costs are relatively small as a fraction of the overall payments across five years, constituting approximately .006 and .016 of total payments to common and private property beneficiaries, respectively. The most important household level costs of the program are related to labor engaged in forest conservation activities. Community leaders in beneficiary common properties report on average a greater number of worker days per year spent in fire prevention (+66 days), pest control (+17 days), and forest patrols (+142 days) compared to nonbeneficiary common properties. Valuing all labor„both paid and unpaid„at the minimum wage, we estimate that the median ratio of the cost of additional labor in beneficiary communities relative to the amount of the payments is 0.84.

Title: Implementing REDD_ at the local level: Assessing the key enablers for credible mitigation and sustainable livelihood outcomes
Author_affil: Sustainability Research Institute, School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds, LS2 9JT, Leeds, UK
Funding: This research was funded by a University of Leeds International Research Scholarship and the ASB-Partnership (3109 6332 NORD- 886.01 GBL008) for the Tropical Forest Margin of the World Agroforestry Centre. The scoping study for this work was funded through fieldwork bursaries from the University of Leeds' Sustainability Research Institute.
Stated_int: Reducing emissions from avoided deforestation and forest degradation (REDD_) has gained both institutional legitimacy and critique on its ability to link carbon management to human development in practice
Desired_out: The global REDD_ design rules recognize emissions reductions and livelihoods as key outcomes expected from implementing REDD_
Study_goal: This paper aims to identify and discuss the set of local livelihood assets necessary for effective implementation of REDD_ at the local level drawing on evidence from the ongoing implementation of the Kasigau REDD_ project in Kenya. The specific objectives of the study are: (1) to evaluate how a globally linked REDD_ project engages the local community in its activities; (2) to identify the livelihood assets that significantly influence the project's ability to protect forests; (3) to analyse project impacts on livelihood assets and forest conservation; (4) to analyse the role of the State in the project's implementation. The next section unpacks policy implementation as this study's conceptual framework.
Study_location: Kasigau Corridor REDD+ project in Kenya's Coastal region
Stated_outcomes: Wilcoxon matched pairs signed test for differences between project impacts (intervention) and expected (control).

Title: Benefits to local communities from community conservancies in Namibia: an assessment
Author_affil: Senior Environmental Economist, Environment Department, World Bank, Washington, DC, USA
Funding: Donors from the Trust Fund for Environmental and Socially Sustainable Development; the Swedish Government for funding through Sida; and the UK Government for funding through the DFID
Stated_int: Community-oriented conservation in Namibia
Desired_out: economic development, empowerment, and conservation
Int_dur: Communal conservancies in Namibia established in 1995
Study_goal: This article evaluates the benefits of community-based activities in wildlife conservancies in Namibia by asking three questions: Do community conservancies contribute to an increase in household welfare? Are such programmes pro-poor; that is, do they improve welfare more for poorer households than for the less poor? Does participation in conservancy increase household welfare more for participants than non-participants?
Study_location: Two regions of Namibia, Kunene to the northwest and Caprivi in the northeast
Stated_outcomes: Impact of established conservancy programmes on household welfare (measured by household income, per-capita income, household expenditure and per-capita expenditure) relative to comparator conservancies; Determinants and impacts of participation in the established conservancies
Portion_livelihood_amount: Table 3 shows average income from conservancies in each of the study areas

outcome.Indicators: Labor allocation changes as a result of mangrove forest loss
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: The total effect of a loss in mangrove area is to reduce the supply of male labour to outside employment but to increase the supply of female members. outcome.Indicators: Participation in conservation efforts of mangrove-dependent households
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: The results show that the male decision to participate is mostly influenced by household awareness of community conservation efforts and use rules, as shown by the positive coefficient and highest marginal probability. The degree of mangrove-dependent income is the second-most important positive influence, with a marginal probability of 0.28. The householdÍs awareness of the environmental impact of shrimp farming is the other significant variable in the male equation. The positive coefficient value and marginal probability of 0.13 suggest that males from households that are aware of the negative environmental impact of shrimp farms are more likely to participate in replanting. For females, the degree of dependence of the household on mangrove-based income is significant at the 10% level and is the most important variable influencing its participation. Distance to the mangroves from the household is the next most important influence.

Title: Mangrove Dependency and the Livelihoods of Coastal Communities in Thailand
Journal: Book: CAB International 2006. Environment and Livelihoods in Tropical Coastal Zones (eds C.T. Hoanh, T.P. Tuong, J.W. Gowing and B. Hardy)
Author_affil: Department of Economics and Finance, University of Wyoming, Laramie, Wyoming, USA
Stated_int: The expansion of intensive shrimp farming in the coastal areas of southern Thailand has led to rapid conversion of mangroves (deforestation of mangrove forests)
Desired_out: Increase annual shrimp production through aquaculture
Int_dur: Mangrove conversion for aquaculture began in Thailand as early as 1974, but the boom in intensive shrimp farming through mangrove clearing took off in 1985 when the increasing demand for shrimp in Japan pushed up the border-equivalent price to $100/kg.
Study_goal: A case study of the labour allocation decisions of rural households from four representative villages illustrates the importance of mangroves to the livelihoods of coastal communities in Thailand. Study assesses the impacts of mangrove loss on labour allocation decisions.
Study_location: The four case study villages are Ban Khlong Khut and Ban Gong Khong in Nakhon Si Thammarat Province on the Gulf of Thailand, and Ban Sam Chong Tai and Ban Bang Pat in Phangnga Province on the Andaman Sea.
Study_duration: A randomly stratified survey at the four village study sites was conducted during April and July 2000.
Stated_outcomes: Mangrove Loss and Labour Allocation in the Case Study Villages; Mangrove Dependency and Participation in Conservation Efforts
Portion_livelihood_amount: Mangrove-dependent income share of total income varies by outside employment by household type groups, and by village, and ranges from 66%-95%.

Title: In the wake of tsunami: Lessons learned from the household decision to replant mangroves in Thailand
Author_affil: Department of Economics and Finance, University of Wyoming, Laramie, WY 82071-3985, USA
Stated_int: Voluntary mangrove replanting schemes subsequent to the 2004 tsunami
Desired_out: Rehabilitate mangrove ecosystems as ïïnatural barriersÍÍ to future tsunamis and other tropical storms
Study_goal: The analysis focuses on how various factors influence the willingness of mangrove dependent households to participate in local replanting efforts in four case study villages in Thailand.
Study_location: Two study sites, one in Nakhon Si Thammarat Province on the east coast, or Gulf of Thailand, and one in Phang-nga Province on the west coast, or the Indian Ocean (Andaman Sea), At each site households in two different villages were surveyed, Ban Sam Chong Tai and Ban Bang Pat in Phang-nga and Ban Khong Khut and Ban Gong Khong in Nakhon Si Thammarat.
Comps_notes: Sample split by the type of mangrove activities the household was predominately involved in (fish only; collect only; fish & collect)
Stated_outcomes: Participation in mangrove replanting

Title: Cockles in custody: The role of common property arrangements in the ecological sustainability of mangrove fisheries on the Ecuadorian coast
Author_affil: Department of Anthropology, University of Georgia, Georgia, USA
Funding: National Science Foundation DDIG_BCS_0819376, the Wenner Gren Foundation, and the Fulbright program
Stated_int: Common property resource management
Desired_out: Custodia management plan has two main objectives: 1) mangrove conservation and restoration; 2) specific guidelines for the sustainable management of the cockle fishery
Study_goal: "...illustrate the relationship between the institutional arrangements of the custodia in Isla Costa Rica and their effects on the resource through a comparative analysis of three types of management regimes: 1) Custodia Managed Fishery, areas tightly managed by rotation and fishery closures in Isla Costa Rica; 2) Custodia Open Fishery, areas of the concession in which the  fishery is not tightly managed because of limited resources (human capital, lack of boats and money for gas); 3) Absence of Custodias, areas outside the concession frequented by collectors from Isla Costa Rica, neighboring communities, and the Port of Hualtaco and where access is de ned by a first-come, first-serve basis."
Study_location: Isla Costa Rica and Puerto Hualtaco
Stated_outcomes: Number of shells collected per hour (CPUE/hr), perception of benefits from custodias

Title: Equity in Community Forests in Bhutan
Author_affil: University of Rhode Island, Dept. of Natural Resources Science, 1 Greenhouse Road, Kingston, Rl 02881, USA
Funding: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) and Helvetas
Stated_int: Community forestry
Desired_out: Initiated to increase community participation in management of national forests. Community forest legislation enables traditional users of national forest to apply or legal rights to manage block of national forest through formation of community forestry management group (CFMG) who liaise with Department of Forests on management plans.
Study_goal: Two main research questions addressed: 1). Does the initial experience with community forestry in Bhutan indicate emerging problems with political and economic equity as documented in neighbouring countries? 2). How do Bhutan's cultural, political and geographic conditions affect the equity of its community forestry program?
Study_location: Yakpugang CF (7 15'N, 91 16'E),  Masangdaza CF (7 15'N, 91 10'E), Shambayung CF (27 36'N, 90 53'E)
Stated_outcomes: Economic equity (number of timber trees allocated, firewood collection, number of livestock grazing, NWFP collection), political equity (participation in decision-making, perception of equitable benefit sharing)

Title: ENVIRONMENTAL AND EXCHANGE ENTITLEMENTS FROM EUCALYPTUS WOODLOTS: THE CASE OF MUKONO DISTRICT IN UGANDA
Author_affil: Makerere University, Faculty of Forestry and Nature Conservation, P.O. Box 7062, Kampala, Uganda
Funding: Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (Norad)
Stated_int: Cultivation of Eucalyptus through taungya techniques
Desired_out: "Taungya is a form of land rent in kind where the taungya farmers don't directly pay the tree farmers but provide free labour for certain tasks such as clearing the land, weeding and biomass waste management to tree farmers who in tum allow them to grow their crops under trees. Under taungya arrangement, there is normally no written agreement between the tree farmer and taungya practitioner. The latter party according to the unwritten agreement must clear or prepare the land and grow annual crops. Taungya farmers must weed trees and are not allowed to kill, destroy or vandalise any young plant or undertake any tree tending operations."
Study_goal: "How and when do different resource claimants gain access to the benefits from woodlots? How are these entitlements appropriated?"
Study_location: Mukono district
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with planted trees, trees on farms, or tree farms
Stated_outcomes: Employment from taungya practices, collection of firewood
Stated_mech: Environmental entitlements framework (Leach et al. 1999)

Title: Accounting for single and aggregated forest incomes: Application to public cork oak forests in Jerez (Spain) and Iteimia (Tunisia)
Author_affil: Institute of Economics and Geography, Spanish Council for Scientific Research (CSIC), Pinar 25, 28006 Madrid, Spain
Funding: Spanish Agency for International Cooperation (AECI), the European Commission, and the Tunisian Ministry of Research
Linked_refs: Sustainable silvopastoral management models in Mediterranean forests: Application to cork oak forests in Spain (Cadiz) and Tunisia (Ain Draham); and Conservation and Restoration of European cork oak woodlands: a unique ecosystem in the balance (CREOAK)
Stated_int: Cork agroforestry/silvopastoral system ownership system
Desired_out: "In the case of Jerez, the public landowner has a right to exclude others from using the forest resources; community employment and natural resource conservation criteria determine Jerez's management. In the Iteimia case, the public landowner has regulated free-use rights for livestock grazing, firewood and crops so that local households can meet their needs and improve their income. Households operate by maximizing their income from the full employment of their own family workforce"
Study_goal: "The major objective of this paper is to improve the application of AAS methodology to two public Mediterranean cork oak forest case studies (Jerez in Spain and Iteimia in Tunisia). To carry out this approach, we compare land ownership, labour market and local economy similarities and dissimilarities in each case study and the differences in the cork oak forest management objectives. Our aim is not to carry out a statistical inference but to perform a comparative income measurement analysis of two cork oak forest with the advantage that there is detailed microeconomic data that enables us to make an in-depth analysis of the natural resource conservation and total commercial income measure- ment from the perspectives of Spain's developed economy and Tunisia's developing economy"
Study_location: Jerez estate (Alcornocales Natural Park, Andalusia), Iteimia estate (Ain Snoussi region)
Stated_outcomes: Labour income, capital income

Title: Development and testing of a sustainable environmental restoration policy on eradicating the poverty trap in ChinaÍs Changting County
Author_affil: College of Water and Soil Conservation, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing, 100083, China
Stated_int: Property rights reform, payments for ecosystem services
Desired_out: Reformed property rights for forested land, allocating 90% of lands to individual farmers. As this did not protect trees as expected, county government initiated a new development policy in 2000 to promote both environmental conservation and poverty reduction. "The policy provided annual compensation of RMB 10 million (US$1 equaled approximately RMB 8.27 in 2000) from the provinceÍs budget in areas that were experiencing the heaviest soil erosion." Compensation was for soil and water conservation practices.
Study_goal: "In the present paper, our goals were to evaluate the potential links between environmental policy and environmental and social sustainability by presenting an approach that combines the need to protect both nature and society. This approach provides a good example of how to improve the benefits of environmental restoration while simultaneously protecting the livelihoods of those who are most directly affected by the program. Our study had the major objective of comparing the effectiveness of subsidy programs that promote environmental restoration with and without additional measures taken to ensure the livelihoods of the residents will be protected when the subsidies end."
Study_location: 5 villages in each of 4 towns (Cewu, Hetian, Sanzhou, Zhuotian) in Changting County. 5 towns in 14 villages outside of the project area
Stated_outcomes: Economic improvements (methane generation facilities added, number of workers employed in soil and water conservation, income from alternative livelihoods - pigs, fruit trees, aquaculture)

Title: Community forestry management and livelihood development in northwest China: integration of governance, project design, and community participation
Author_affil: Chair of Forest and Nature Conservation Policy, Georg-August-University Goettingen, Buesgenweg 3, 37077 Goettingen, Germany
Funding: Unclear
Stated_int: Community-based co-management of forest resources
Desired_out: "Key characteristics of CBCM projects are as follows. (1) CBCM projects provide non-agricultural work and employment information from outside the community to help participants improve their livelihood condition. (2) They facilitate the positive participation of local community residents in the management of natural resources. (3) Most CBCM projects aim to communicate to participants a stronger awareness of forest resource protection. Increased consciousness typically results in reduced or more conservative collection of forest products. (4) They provide training on agricultural techniques to enable farmers to improve crop production, optimize cultivation practices, and increase agricultural production outcomes"
Study_goal: "...analyze the changes in livelihood development and community forestry management under the influence of CBCM projects. Analyses focused on four groups of attributes: social correlates of current and future participation; fair- ness and CBCM performance; forest health; and economic benefits from CBCM participation"
Study_location: Gansu Baishuijiang National Nature Reserve, located in Wenxian County, Gansu Province, China
Stated_outcomes: Perceptions of economic benefits of CBCM participation

Title: Law Enforcement in Community Forestry: Consequences for the Poor
Author_affil: Institute of Forestry, Pokhara Campus, P.O Box: 43, Hariyokharka, Pokhara, Nepal
Funding: University of Copenhagen and the Consultative Research Committee (FFU) at the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Grant No. 104.Dan.8.L.716
Stated_int: Community Forestry program
Desired_out: Community-based forest management implemented as part of effort to decentralize forest management. Runs as a binding agreement between each community forest user group (CFUG) and Nepalese government with approved 5 year work plans that specific management objectives and activities, with methods of forest protection.
Study_goal: The study attempts to "(1) documents officially recorded forest crimes, (2) explores perceptions of the nature, severity and causes of forest crimes in community forests held by main stakeholders at local and central levels, and (3) investigates current forest crimes and penalties in 14 case CFUGs."
Study_location: Simjung and Gyachchok CFUGs of Gorkha District
Stated_outcomes: Impact of forest law enforcement on economic equity, impact of forest law enforcement on social equity

Title: Payments for biodiversity conservation in the context of weak institutions: Comparison of three programs from Cambodia
Author_affil: Wildlife Conservation Society, 2300 Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10460, USA; Department of Zoology, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge, CB2 3EJ, UK
Funding: United States Agency for International Development (USAID), under the terms of the TransLinks Cooperative Agreement No. EPP-A-00-06-00014-00 to WCS, the University of Cambridge and a Royal Society Wolfson Research Merit award to E.J.M.G., as well as support from WCS, Edith McBean, the Global Environment Facility, United Nations Development Program, the Danish International Cooperation Agency, the UK Department for International Development (DfID), IUCN Netherlands and the Jeniam Foundation
Stated_int: Payments for ecosystem services, community-based ecotourism initiated as a complement to existing protected areas

Title: Impact of participatory forestry program on sustainable rural livelihoods: Lessons from an Indian province
Author_affil: Centre for Studies in Social Sciences, Calcutta (CSSSC), India
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management (JFM) and female forest protection committees (FPC)
Desired_out: Participatory approach to community forestry - institutionalization of forest protection with involvement of stakeholders. Specifically, devolution of decision-maker power and responsibility to local communications under community titling property rights approach to manage forest lands. Specifically within the JFM program, West Bengal establishment of female forest protection committees (FPC) to empower women in decision-making sphere.
Study_goal: Assess the impact of participatory forestry initiatives on livelihoods sustainability across the socioeconomic groups of rural poor in forest fringe areas at the micro level
Study_location: Agua, Malibona, Brindabanpur, Belboni, Baragari, Katul-II, Kustara, Majdiha villages in Bankura district, West Bengal
Stated_outcomes: Natural capital, physical capital, financial capital, human capital, social capital
Portion_livelihood_amount: Varies, see Table 5 in paper

Title: Assessment of community-based initiatives in sustainable management of Indian dry deciduous forests
Journal: International Journal of Sustainable Development & World Ecology
Author_affil: Department of Agricultural and Food Engineering , Indian Institute of Technology;  Department of Geography, Taki Government College.
Stated_int: Forest protection committees (FPC) as implemented in Joint Forest Management at local forest management unit (FMU) level
Desired_out: Program focused on creation of FPCs to initiate partnerships between village communities and the state forest department for monitoring JFM, drafting plans, protecting forests from grazing and illegal harvesting, while the forests continued to be owned by the Forest Department. Joint management of forest lands and shared responsibility for regenerating degraded land would lead to sharing of benefits from timber and NTFPs.
Study_goal: "In this study, a previously developed C&I framework was applied for assessment of functioning of forest protection committees (FPCs) in the dry deciduous forests of India through a 5-year monitoring programme"
Study_location: Nayagram Forest Range
Stated_outcomes: Social capital of forest protection committees, income, governance structure

Title: Livelihoods Generation and Poverty Reduction Attempts in Joint Forest Management Activities in Madhya Pradesh
Author_affil: Indian Institute of Forest Management, Mehru Nagar, Bhopal, India
Funding: None listed
Stated_int: Madhya Pradesh Forestry Project. Two phase project. Phase I funded by World Bank with IDA credit intended to fulfill Joint Forest Management objectives
Desired_out: "The project was designed to meet this felt need for investment in the forestry sector. The project was designed after a prolonged dialogue within the forest department and with the various other stakeholder groups of the state. The project provided funds not only for investment in the upgrading of the forestry technology and forest floor management; it also mandated the upgrading of the skills and knowledge of the staff, both in traditional forestry and modern concepts. Above all, it put high emphasis on the participation of the forest dwellers in the management of the nearby forests and sharing the benefits...."
Study_goal: Report on project outcomes
Study_location: Madhya Pradesh
Stated_outcomes: Involvement of forest-users in decision-making, women involvement in decision making, livelihood generation, poverty reduction

Title: Decentralization, market integration and efficiency-equity trade-offs: Evidence from Joint Forest Management in Ethiopian villages
Author_affil: School of Economics, University of Cape Town, Rondebosch, Cape Town 7701, South Africa
Funding: Volkswagen Foundation and University of Johannesburg, Economic Research Southern Africa, EfD (EDRI/EEPFE) SIDA
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management, community forest enterprises, marketing of NTFPs
Desired_out: "The general objectives of these programs are to arrest deforestation and forest degradation while improving the welfare of those who are heavily dependent on the forest for their livelihoods. In essence, the programs are intended to achieve these twin goals by incentivizing local communities to manage state forests. However, there are pervasive imperfections in forest products markets that constrain the needed incentives; these imperfections arise mainly from limited infrastructure, high transport costs, few buyers, exploitive marketing chains and imperfect price information. One innovative approach to overcome these problems, which has been adopted by the Ethiopian government, is to organize JFM into community forest enterprises (CFE) in the form of forest usersÍ cooperatives (FUC) for forest products marketing.4 This provides the community with avenues for greater participation in value chains of forest products markets through vertical integration (VI) (Antinori, 2005; Gelo and Koch, 2014; Vega and Keenan, 2014). Vertical integration is expected to raise NTFP prices and hence spurs the required incentives by shortening the marketing chain and increasing bargaining power of farmers along NTFP market value chain."
Study_goal: "It is aimed at evaluating the income and distributive effects of a JFM program augmented by market linkage interventions."
Study_location: Gimbo District
Stated_outcomes: Changes in household welfare

Study_goal: The objectives of this study are (i) to examine the contribution of PFM to local livelihoods in terms of incomes of households organized under the program; (ii) to assess the effects of PFM in empowering poor women and minorities in terms of participation, benefit sharing and decision making, and (iii) to determine and quantify the changes in forest status by comparing forests under and outside PFM.
Study_location: Bonga district
Study_duration: 2002-2007: Bonga PFM is initiated and ran by FARM Africa. The project had two phases: the first phase ran for 8 years between 1995 and 2002. The second phase, which was the focus of this study, lasted between 2002 and 2007.
Stated_outcomes: Change in household income before/after PFM introduced
Portion_livelihood_amount: See Figures 1 & 2 in paper

Title: Harnessing butterfly biodiversity for improving livelihoods and forest conservation: The Kipepeo Project
Author_affil: Environmental Health Division at the International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology
Funding: Global Environment Facility Small Grants Programme, the IUCN-Netherlands Tropical Rain Forest Programme, the Biodiversity Support Program, a consortium of World Wildlife Fund, the Nature Conservancy, and the World Resources Insti- tute, with funding by the United States Agency for International Devel- opment, the Chicago Zoological Society and Brookfield Zoo, the National Museums of Kenya, and the EU-funded BirldLife International Arabuko-Sokoke Forest Management and Conservation Project
Stated_int: The Kipepeo Project
Desired_out: "a project administered by the East Africa Natural History Society (EANHS, now Nature Kenya [NK]) in partnership with the National Museums of Kenya (NMK). Kipepeo was started in 1993 with $50,000 from the Global Environment Facility (GEF) Small Grants Programme. Its objective was to change local attitudes by enabling the forest-adjacent community to get cash incomes from rearing forest butterflies for export to the live butterfly exhibit industry in Europe and America"
Study_goal: Self-evaluation of Kipepeo project. How much has it added value to Arabuko-Sokoke Forest? Has it affected local attitudes to the forest? How much has it succeeded in improving community livelihoods? Have there been any unanticipated negative effects? Have the earnings been evenly spread? Have the socially and economically disadvantaged sections of the community benefited from Kipepeo? Have there been any other spin-offs for conservation? Has butterfly harvest- ing for farming operations affected wild butterfly populations in the forest? Is Kipepeo sustainable? Can it be replicated?
Study_location: villages around Arabuko-Sokoke Forest
Stated_outcomes: Added value to forest, contribution to cash incomes, empowerment of community to represent forest

Stated_int: Decision 10/QD.UB (22/09/2010), mangrove forest management, shrimp aquaculture

Title: Mangrove conservation or shrimp farmerÍs livelihood? The devolution of forest management and benefit sharing in the Mekong Delta, Vietnam
Author_affil: Environmental Policy Group, Wageningen University, Hollandseweg 1, 6706 KN Wageningen, The Netherlands; Department of Economics, Faculty of Economics and Business Management, Vietnam Forestry University, Xuan Mai Town, Ha Noi City, Viet Nam
Stated_int: Song Trem Forest-Fishery Enterprise, decentralized forest management, Red Book certificate program, mangrove-based shrimp aquaculture
Desired_out: "The policies are regarded as an important strategy to encourage local people to participate in forest planting and protection. They have been implemented in all the regions of Vietnam from upland to lowland forest areas. In accordance with forest allocation policies, a national benefit sharing policy in forest protection and development became operational. This policy is based on three principles aiming at ensuring harmony between: the state and the forest usersÍ interests; economic benefits and the ecological functions of forests; and between short-term and long-term benefits to make sure that forest users can live on forestry"
Study_goal: "Using the case of integrated shrimp mangrove farming system in Ca Mau province, the Mekong Delta the paper aims at investigating how changes in legal rights associated with the devolution of forest management, are related to actual rights and the distribution of benefits out of forest management practices and influence shrimp farmersÍ decisions with respect to the management of mangroves"
Study_location: Ngoc Hien and Nam Can districts in Ca Mau province
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with natural vegetation
Stated_outcomes: Income from mangrove cutting vs. shrimp farming, land allocated to households

Title: Dry land tree management for improved household livelihoods: Farmer managed natural regeneration in Niger
Author_affil: Mickey Leland International Hunger Fellow of the Congressional Hunger Center, 400 North Capitol Street NW Suite G100, Washington, D.C. 20001, USA
Funding: ICRISAT, Bioversity International, and World Vision Australia
Stated_int: Farmer managed natural regeneration
Desired_out: "In 1983 an international aid and missionary organization called Society of International Ministries (SIM, subsequently renamed as Serving in Mission) began promoting FMNR as a component of its Maradi Integrated Development Project (MIDP). When drought and famine struck the region in 1984 and 1988, MIDP included FMNR as part of a Food for Work program. This program was extended to 95 villages in the districts of Dakoro, Guidan Roumdji, and Madar- ounfa, and exposed an estimated 80,000 to 100,000 farmers to FMNR."
Study_goal: "We address three key questions. First, how widespread is adoption of the tree conservation and management practices to which NigerÍs re-greening has been attributed? Second, what factors determine a farmerÍs likelihood of adopting such practices? And third, what are the impacts of adoption of these practices on household livelihood outcomes?"
Study_location: Maradi region
Stated_outcomes: Impact of adoption of FMR on per capita gross income, crop diversity, tree density, tree diversity, migrant per household

Title: How Can Social Safeguards of REDD+ Function Effectively Conserve Forests and Improve Local Livelihoods? A Case from Meru Betiri National Park, East Java, Indonesia
Author_affil: Graduate School of Bioagricultural Sciences, Department of Biosphere Resources Science, Nagoya University, Nagoya 4648601, Japan
Funding: Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research (A) 22255012, (A) 24248026 and (C) 23510316 by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science, and Japan Securities Scholarship Foundation in 2009
Stated_int: REDD+, Meru Betiri National Park
Desired_out: "The stated objective is to contribute to tropical forest conservation by enhancing community participation in conservation activities and sustainable park management. The project aims to achieve the following objectives: (1) to improve the livelihoods of local communities living inside and in the area surrounding the park and (2) to develop a credible measuring, reporting, and verifying (MRV) system for monitoring the reduction of emissions caused by deforestation and forest degradation and for enhancing forest carbon stocks in MBNP. The specific outputs from activities are: (1) improved participation of the local community in forest management; (2) developing alternative sources of income to improve the livelihoods of local communities living inside and in the area surrounding MBNP; (3) reduction and reporting of illegal logging and forest encroachment; (4) improving the capacity to conduct an inventory of the resource base and carbon accounting in a measurable, reportable, and verifiable form; (5) preparing a report on comprehensive baseline data and an estimation of the emissions reduction and carbon stock enhancement of the national park; and (6) establishing and validating a system for monitoring emissions reductions and the enhancement of carbon stocks."
Study_goal: "This study investigates whether REDD+ projects could generate sufficient economic incentives and social motivations for local people through participating in protecting forests, and draws implications for developing a national REDD+ strategy suitable for circumstances in the field. The research objectives have been: (1) to assess how the relationships between local people and national park authorities have been established through the REDD+ project; (2) to identify the positive social and economic impacts of the REDD+ project on local people; (3) to make clear local awareness of the national park and REDD+ project; and (4) to make clear motivations for participating in the REDD+ project. "
Study_location: Curahnongko, Sanenrejo villages inside and outside Meru Betiri National Park, Jawa Timur
Stated_outcomes: Difference in income between participants vs. non-participants

Title: Certification of a Community-based Forest Enterprise for Improving Institutional Management and Household Income: A Case from Southeast Sulawesi, Indonesia
Author_affil: School of Human Science and Environment, University of Hyogo, 1-1-12, Shinzaike-honcho, Himeji, Hyogo 670-0092, Japan
Funding: Forest Conservation Project, Institute for Global Environmental Strategies (IGES), Japan, Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research in 2011 and 2012 [(A) 22255012, (C) 23510316] and in 2012 [(A) 24248026], by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science
Stated_int: Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) certification
Desired_out: "Activities carried out by TFT (Tropical Forest Trust), JAUH (Forest Network) and KHJL (cooperative for sustainable forests) with local people included: (1) introducing community forest certification programs to communities in 12 villages; (2) registering new members possessing teak forests; (3) organizing forest management training for KHJL staff; (4) creating community forest maps; (5) arranging an inventory of standing teak stocks; and (6) arranging documents necessary for acquiring certification. KHJL prepared for acquiring certification by: (1) making financial regulations for managing certified wood; (2) making standard operation procedures including membership, finance, forest inventory, monitoring, cutting trees and sawmill operation; and (3) preparing the management plan."
Study_goal: "This study investigates how FSC group certification can improve situations of community forest management while using forests in a sustainable manner, in the South Konawe district in Southeast Sulawesi, and draws implications for better community forestry in developing countries. The research objectives have been: (1) to assess how post-certification activities as a whole, including member regulations and producing certified wood, affect local communities; and (2) to analyze specific cases to evaluate how local people have been encouraged to accommodate certification for developing their community forest."
Study_location: South Konawe district, South Sulawesi province (3Á58.660_4Á31.520 S, 121Á58_123Á160 E)
Stated_outcomes: costs of timber extraction and transportation, land area allocated, value of product, overall income

Title: Resource Use and Ecosystem Services in a Forest Park Landscape
Author_affil: Department of Geography, University of New Hampshire, Durham, New Hampshire, USA
Funding: National Science Foundation (number 0352008), the University of Florida (UF) Center for African Studies David L. Niddrie Memorial Scholarship, and a Working Forests in the Tropics Field Research Grant
Stated_int: Kibale National Park
Desired_out: Protect critical ecosystem
Study_goal: "The objective of this study was to gain a better understanding of local importance and uses of wetlands and forest fragments within the landscape surrounding Kibale, a forest park amidst dense agricultural settlement. I hypothesize that use of these areas depended on location, size for wetland or forest fragment, and demographic characteristics. Two questions are addressed: (1) What ecosystem goods and services are associated with wetlands and forest fragments2 around Kibale? (2) How do these goods and services vary by distance to the park boundary, distance to fragment, size of fragment, gender, wealth, and ethnicity?"
Study_location: Villages to east and west of Kibale National Park
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with natural vegetation
Stated_outcomes: Perceived benefits from forests and wetlands in Kibale National Park

Title: An institutional analysis of Payment for Environmental Services on collectively managed lands in Ecuador
Author_affil: Institute of Public Service and Environmental Studies, Seattle University, 901 12th Ave, Seattle, WA 98122, United States; Center for the Study of Population, Institutions and Environmental Change (CIPEC), Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47408, United States
Funding: National Science Foundation (grant # SES 1156271) and the Seattle University Center for Environmental Justice and Sustainability
Stated_int: Payments for Ecosystem Services, Programa Socio Bosque, Programa Socio Paramo
Desired_out: "In 2008, the Ecuadorian government instated PSB with the dual goals of preventing the destruction and degradation of native ecosystems, and increasing income and human capital in the poorest communities of Ecuador." "...Payments are intended to act as an incentive or compensation for conservation behaviors; the payments are not based on calculated opportunity costs." In July 2009, a sector of PSB was designated to focus on the paramo, particularly areas that are threatened, provide ecosystem services, and located in the poorest regions.
Study_goal: "an exploratory study that examines how participation in an Ecuadorian payment for conservation program, Programa Socio Bosque (PSB), is associated with communal resource management. Specifically, we examine (i) the presence of communal land-use rules and assess the degree to which PES participation, particularly PES payment, corresponds with the development of these rules; (ii) the characteristics of the communities that are making rule changes to produce additional conservation benefits as compared to those that are paid to maintain the status quo; and (iii) the application of the rule systems."
Study_location: Ecuadorian Andes paramo ecosystems
Stated_outcomes: Yearly payment in relationship to change in grazing rules

Title: Household participation in a Payments for Environmental Services programme: the Nhambita Forest Carbon Project (Mozambique)
Author_affil: Horticulture Australia, Economic Analysis, 3 Sligo Place, Prestons, NSW 2170, Australia
Funding: Financial support is acknowledged from the Hampton Grant from the University of British Columbia, the World Bank administered Trust Fund for Environmentally and Socially Sustainable Development through the Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR), and the International Development Research Centre (IDRC) through a Doctoral Research Fellowship.
Stated_int: PES Program: small-scale agro-forestry based carbon sequestration pilot programme, known as the Nhambita Carbon Livelihoods Project
Desired_out: The programme aims to conserve and regenerate the miombo woodlands by offering both conditional financial compensation (i.e., PES) and alternative livelihood options through a community development component.
Int_dur: Initiated in 2002; pilot phase 2002-2008; continued after 2008
Study_goal: Using econometric analysis, we determine socio-economic factors influencing household participation, focusing on self-selection bias in the participant sample.
Study_location: Chicale Regulado (Traditional Authority), located in the buffer zone of the Gorongosa National Park (GNP) in Sofala Province, Mozambique. The pilot phase was limited to the villages of Nhambita, Bue Maria and Munhanganha, and was later expanded to Mbalawa and Pungue.
Stated_outcomes: Factors influencing program participation

Stated_int: Biodiversity in the form of wild foods
Desired_out: Increased food security for poor & rural households
Study_goal: This paper empirically quantifies and analyses (i) the economic contribution of wild foods to rural households, (ii) the household socio-economic, demographic, and geographical correlates of wild food income, and (iii) how wild foods can be better incorporated into integrative food security policies.

Author_affil: Research Institute for the Environment and Livelihoods, Charles Darwin University, Darwin, Northern Territory, Australia; Center for International Forestry Research, Bogor, Indonesia
Funding: Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR), the Australian Agency for International Development, and the Research Institute for the Environment and Livelihoods (formerly the School for Environmental Research) at Charles Darwin University in Australia
Stated_int: Liulong Farm Bamboo Migrant Project
Desired_out: "Partnership between county government and private company involved in bamboo shoot processing and marketing, and is part of a province and nationwide voluntary rural resettlement program associated with the nationÍs wider rural poverty alleviation strategy." Migrants relocated from areas of high poverty, low opportunity to area to grow bamboo as cash crops. Plantation with housing and amenities built, along with infrastructure. "Migrants entered into a contractual relationship with both the county government (for the land) and the company (for the bamboo shoots), whereby the migrants were allowed to use their land only for growing bamboo and were under contract to sell their bamboo shoots exclusively to the company (the end market for the shoots was mostly Japan or Taiwan)."
Study_goal: "The aim of this paper is to assess the links between smallholder bamboo management practices, shoot yield (productivity), income, and livelihoods in a poor and mountainous county in southern China."
Study_location: 12 villages (2 migrant, 10 local) in Tianlin County (24 _ 258N, 105 _ 1068E)
Stated_outcomes: changes in productivity, income sources, perceptions of change in income

Title: Forest restoration to achieve both ecological and economic progress, Poyang Lake basin, China
Author_affil: The Institute of Geographical Sciences and Natural Resources Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 100101 Beijing, China
Funding: National Natural Science Foundation of China (40971281, 41001366) and the Ministry of Science and Technology 973 Program (2009CB421105)
Stated_int: Mountain-River-Lake Program, forest restoration, lake and river restoration, poverty alleviation
Desired_out: "The Mountain-River-Lake Program (MRL) was launched in ChinaÍs Poyang Lake basin in 1983, and focused on eco-restoration and poverty reduction."..."The MRL program provides access to technology, financial resources and information to farmers who directly manage the ecosystems. Since 1997, participatory methods were introduced that involve farmers in the entire process of problem analysing, project planning, decision making, implementing, monitoring and evaluating, and follow-up management." "To move farmers away from a form of forestry that was focused on harvesting wood for fuel, the government encouraged the con- struction of infrastructure to provide methane generation facilities for every household. To increase the net income of farmers, addi- tional farming activities such as planting fruit trees, and raising pigs and fishes, were encouraged." "The government encouraged the transfer of land ownership to residents who were willing to plant trees and prohibit tree felling"
Study_goal: "To assess the efficacy of such a huge program, when the whole community was involved in pursuing a well-articulated environ- mental restoration and poverty reduction strategy, we evaluated the programÍs impacts by rigorous before and after comparisons in Poyang Lake basin, and identify the potential links between environmental policy and sustainability development"
Study_location: Poyang Lake basin (181 representative villages)
Stated_outcomes: Ecological effectiveness (forest cover, carbon sequestration, soil and water conservation), change in net income, ratio of net income to net consumption expenditure, change in number of persons below poverty line

Title: EXPECTATIONS, IMPACTS AND ATTITUDES: CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT IN CROSS RIVER NATIONAL PARK, NIGERIA
Author_affil: Department of Geography, Cambridge University, UK
Funding: University of Cambridge from the Cambridge Commonwealth Trust. Grants and awards were also received from the Philip Lake Fund II, Bartle Frere Exhibition, Smuts Memorial Fund, and Churchill College. Further financial assistance was provided by the Overseas Research Students (ORS) award, Sutasoma Charitable Trust, Sir Ernest Cassell Educational Trust and the Humanitarian Trust
Stated_int: Support Zone Development Programme (SZDP), Cross River National Park
Desired_out: "The CRNP could achieve both the conservation goal of maintaining a globally important ecological area intact, and the development goal of improving the economic and social welfare of local people (Caldecott et al., 1990). This entailed the application of `carrots' of public benefits and a `stick' of regulations and enforcement in the villages within and bordering the Park." "The primary intention of the Support Zone Development Program was therefore to create a bu er zone around the protected forest area in a bid to reduce the apparent threats to the Park from incursion, resource use and forest loss."
Study_goal: "In this paper, we review an attempt to develop an ICDP in association with a TMF national park, Cross River National Park (CRNP) in southeast Nigeria (Figure 1). In the light of the expectations of local participants, we consider resulting attitudes to the park and to the ICDP project"
Study_location: Abo Mkpang, Kanyang 2 and Bokalum villages, Okwangwo Division
Stated_outcomes: Perceived benefits and disadvantages of National Park to households

Title: FOREST INCOMES AFTER UGANDAÍS FOREST SECTOR REFORM: Are the Rural Poor Gaining?
Author_affil: Indiana University
Funding: The Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR); the CGIAR Systemwide Program on Collective Action and Property Rights Initiative (CAPRi); the National Science Foundation (NSF, grant number DDIG 0622392); the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (SSHRC); the Social Science Research Council (SSRC); and the Sustainable Agriculture and Natural Resource Management Collaborative Research Support Program (SANREM CRSP, grant number EPP-A-00- 04-00013-00).
Stated_int: Major forest sector governance reform in Uganda (decentralization): The reform involved changes in the ownership and management of 85 percent of UgandaÍs forested land. A new forest policy, a strategic forest sector plan, and new legislation were developed during the forest sector review process. The centralized Forest Department was dismantled, and the decentralized District Forestry Service (DFS) and the for-profit parastatal National Forestry Authority (NFA) were created.
Desired_out: More sustainable forest management; improved livelihoods.
Study_goal: The study aims to evaluate the effect of forest sector reforms on rural livelihoods
Study_location: 4 forest sites located in the northernmost section of the Albertine Rift; the area stretching between Lake Albert and Lake Edward: Rwenzori Mountains National Park, Bugoma Central Forest Reserve, Budongo Central Forest Reserve, Kasagala Central Forest Reserve were in the baseline; all but Kasagala Central Forest Reserve included in the follow-up.
Study_duration: Baseline: late 2003; follow-up: between October 2006 and August 2007
Stated_outcomes: Impacts on household income by Forest Site and Income Quartile for before and after intervention
Portion_livelihood_amount: Portion is provided by forest site and income group before and after intervention and varies for each. See Table 8 in paper.

Authors: Jumbe C, Angelsen A

outcome.Indicators: Average monthly forest income differentials between participants and non-participants for each study area, by household income level, and by gender. Matching estimates of income gains from forest co-management.
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: Yes see Table 6.3 in paper (raw data). Table 6.4 shows the results of both selection-bias adjusted and unadjusted estimates of the average treatment effects on the treated (ATET).The table shows that selection-bias unadjusted estimates of ATET are consistently negative (except for the female subsample) and not statistically significant across subsamples. This suggests that the program does not increase the income of program participants. Table 6.6 shows male-female income decomposition; Table 6.8 shows high-low (household income category) income decomposition.  From the decomposition analyses, our empirical results show that statistical 'discrimination' is the source of income disparity between male and female participants, accounting for 100 per cent of the total income differential, while the income disparity between high- and low-income participants is mainly due to the differences in endowments. This is consistent with the descriptive data, where high-income households have better endowments than low-income households in terms of age, education and household assets (land, livestock and private woodlots) which affect forest income.

Title: Has Forest Co-management in Malawi Benefited the Poor?
Journal: Book: Political Institutions and Development: Failed Expectations and Renewed Hopes
Stated_int: Devolution of forest rights and management: Forest co-management in Malawi. 1996 National Forestry Policy & National Forestry Program. Specifically, In 1996 the World Bank and the British government, through the Department for International Development initiated a pilot forest co-management program in Malawi.
Desired_out: Sustainable management, improved livelihoods: The program was designed to promote local participation in forest management in exchange for the benefits of long-term sustainable management, such as continued access to fuel wood, poles and non-timber forest products
Study_goal: This chapter seeks to address the following questions: Do the poor benefit from participating in the forest co-management program as intended? Are there any biases in the distribution of forest income among different participants and, if so, what are the sources of inequality?
Study_location: Chimaliro and Liwonde forest reserves, in the North-Central and Southern regions of Malawi, respectively.
Stated_outcomes: Impacts of participation in the forest co-management program on household income
Portion_livelihood_amount: The average monthly forest incomes per household for low- and high-income households are estimated at MK237 ($3'.12) and MK620 ($8.15) respectively, which accounts for 8 per cent of their respective average monthly incomes.

Authors: Jumbe C, Angelsen A

outcome.Indicators: selection bias-adjusted estimates of forest income for participants vs. non-participants
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: In Chimaliro program has minor positive impact on household income, at least in the short run. In contrast, estimates from all the four matching methods in Liwonde are consistently negative and highly significant, suggesting that forest co-management program has negative effects on income of participants. Results are also provided for low vs. high income households, and female vs. male headed households. In general, results from Table 4 suggest that the program generates positive income gains to female participants ranging from MK11 (US$0.14) to MK29 (US$0.39) per month per household, representing an increase in income of between 13% and 65% from what they would have earned had they not participated in the program. day selling of fuelwood along the main road. Similarly, empirical results from all the matching methods in the table indicate that low-income participants earn more forest income by participating in the program. We find that income gains to low income participants lie between MK13 (US$0.18) and MK26 (US$0.34) per month per household, an increase in forest income of between 35% and 98% from what they would have earned without participating in the program.

outcome.Indicators: selection bias-adjusted estimates of forest income for participants vs. non-participants
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: In Chimaliro program has minor positive impact on household income, at least in the short run. In general, results from Table 4 suggest that the program generates positive income gains to female participants ranging from MK11 (US$0.14) to MK29 (US$0.39) per month per household, representing an increase in income of between 13% and 65% from what they would have earned had they not participated in the program. day selling of fuelwood along the main road. Similarly, empirical results from all the matching methods in the table indicate that low-income participants earn more forest income by participating in the program. We find that income gains to low income participants lie between MK13 (US$0.18) and MK26 (US$0.34) per month per household, an increase in forest income of between 35% and 98% from what they would have earned without participating in the program.

Title: Do the Poor Benefit from Devolution Policies? Evidence from Malawi's Forest Co-Management Program
Author_affil: Charles B. L. Jumbe was a research fellow in the Department of Economics and Resource Management, Norwegian University of Life Sciences and is now a research fellow at the Centre for Agricultural Research and Development, Bunda College of Agriculture, Lilongwe, Malawi.
Stated_int: Pilot forest co-management program in Malawi
Desired_out: In 1996, the World Bank (WB) and British Government through the Department for International Development (DFID) supported a pilot forest co-management program in Malawi whose primary objective was to promote local participation in forest management in exchange for various benefits resulting from the long-term sustainable management such as access to fuelwood, poles, and non-timber forest products.
Study_goal: Using household data from Chimaliro and Liwonde forest reserves under pilot forest co-management program in Malawi, this paper seeks to address the following questions: do the poor benefit from participating in the forest co management program as intended? Are there any biases in the distribution of forest income among different participants, and if so, what are the sources of inequality?
Study_location: Chimaliro and Liwonde forest reserves located in the central/northern and southern regions of Malawi.
Stated_outcomes: Forest income: selection bias-adjusted estimates of the program impact on income across participants and non-participants
Portion_livelihood_amount: See Table 1 (Summary Statistics), which provides the monthly forest income and monthly total income for participations, non-participants, and by gender and poverty class.

Title: Do protected areas and conservation incentives contribute to sustainable livelihoods? A case study of Bardia National Park, Nepal
Author_affil: School of Business Management and Economics, University of Sussex, Brighton BN1 9SL, UK
Funding: Rufford Small Grant programme, UK, the Royal Geographical Society, and the World Wildlife Fund, Nepal
Stated_int: Bardia National Park, compensatory and incentive-based programs (IBPs)
Desired_out: Bardia National Park declared to protect lowland Terai ecosystem. Incentive-based programs carried out by various NGOs in form of development projects that aim to support "both social and economic activities within the buffer zone area and wildlife conservation in the park. The IBPs include income generation activities, training, school development, infra- structure support, machine donation, toilet building, scholarship, livestock donation and agricultural support and have been implemented since the early 1990s through joint collaboration between park authorities and international donors"
Study_goal: "this paper uses the sustainable livelihoods approach to examine the livelihood impacts of protected area and conservation incentives at Bardia National Park"
Study_location: Thakurdwara, Shivapur, Suryapatuwa villages, near Bardia National Park
Stated_outcomes: Livelihood capitals (compared between villages), impact of conservation incentives on household livelihoods

Authors: Kaushal K, Melkani V, Kala J

outcome.Indicators: Total expenditure per capita (in Peruvian soles), total income per capita (in Peruvian soles), poverty rate, and extreme poverty rate
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: For households living in a 5-km buffer, protected areas exacerbate extreme poverty. However, protected areas do not have a statistically significant effect on the other three socioeconomic indicators. For households living within a 10-km buffer, the effect of protected areas on extreme poverty vanishes. The effect on expenditure is positive and weakly significant. Hence, there is some indication, but certainly not a strong one, that protected areas may have adverse socioeconomic effects on local communities.

Title: Sustainable poverty alleviation through a forestry project in Tamilnadu State of India
Journal: International Journal of Sustainable Development & World Ecology
Author_affil: Deputy Conservator of Forests, Chinnachokkikulum, Madurai, Tamilnadu, India
Funding: Funding for Allen BlackmanÍs participation was provided by the IDB and the National Space and Aeronautics Administration (NASA) through the Servir Applied Science Team.
Stated_int: Protected areas in the Peruvian Amazon
Desired_out: Biodiversity conservation
Int_dur: Peru's first protected area was created in 1961. As of 2012, Peru had 111 national protected areas and 70 regional or private protected areas.
Study_goal: Our study makes several contributions. To our knowledge, it provides the first rigorous evidence„obtained by controlling for protected areasÍ nonrandom siting„for the Amazon on the effects of protected areas on both forest cover change and local communities. We bring to bear particularly rich data. We compare the effectiveness for both outcomes within the same time frame, thus minimizing potential for bias due to mismatched temporal data. We use detailed household-level data as measured by the Peruvian government, comparing expenditures with a predefined poverty line (rather than a proxy poverty index).
Study_location: Peruvian Amazon
Study_duration: 2007 Peruvian census for household data (household characteristics and expenditure from 2001 to 2006). Only protected areas established before 2000, the first year of our study period, are included in the analysis.
Stated_outcomes: Effect on deforestation. Effects on local communities: total expenditure per capita (in Peruvian soles), total income per capita (in Peruvian soles), poverty rate, and extreme poverty rate.

Authors: KHATRI-CHHETRI A

outcome.Indicators: Contribution of NTFPs extracted from common property to total household gross income based on wealth group; Effect of income level on total NTFPs extraction and dependence on NTFPs; socio-economic determinants of forest dependency
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: Table 7 shows the average share of gross NTFP income from community forest to total income (agriculture + livestock + off farm wages + private forest land) of the households. Forest resource dependence decreases with increase in wealth. Table 6 and Table 7 indicate that the rich households are not all that dependent on common property resources although they use more natural resources in terms of quantity. Table 8 presents the regression results of the effect of income level on total NTFPs extraction and dependence on NTFPs. Regression of NTFPs income to total income and income squared shows that within a range of household income NTFPs extraction increases and then falls with the increase in total income. The second regression of ratio of NTFPs income to total income indicates that a householdÍs dependence decreases gradually with a higher income level. But the positive sign with income squared indicates that NTFPs dependence on forest decreases at an increasing rate. This means that very rich households seldom go to the forest for NTFPs collection. In the regression analysis, only familysize, landholding, and distance from the forest have statisticallysignificant effects on NTFPs extraction in the informal FUG village and these effects are fairly large.

Title: Local Institutions and Forest Products Extraction: Evidence from Forest Management in Nepal
Author_affil: Institute of Agriculture and Animal Science Chitwan, Nepal
Funding: This research received generous financial support from the South Asian Network for Development and Environmental Economics.
Stated_int: Decentralization of forest management in Nepal
Desired_out: Sustainable management of forest resources; improved livelihoods
Study_goal: This study seeks to understand the implications of local institutions on forest products extraction and benefit distribution among the users. It examines NTFPs extraction in two communities: one, a government-sponsored formal forest user group and the other, a self-initiated informal forest user group. The key questions addressed in this paper are the following: (i) what are the rules and regulations of NTFP collection in the two types of forest management systems? (ii) how and to what extent does NTFP use differ among the households? (iii) what socio-economic and institutional factors are correlated with differences in NTFP collection?
Study_location: 2 villages: Chuja with government-sponsored formal FUG, and Gobanpani with self-initiated community forest management in Pyuthan district of Nepal, which is located in the middle mountain region
Stated_outcomes: Impact of different programs on household income: Contribution of NTFPs extracted from common property to total household gross income based on wealth group; Effect of income level on total NTFPs extraction and dependence on NTFPs; socio-economic determinants of forest dependency
Portion_livelihood_amount: Table 4 shows annual average income from private forests for the formal FUG & informal FUG groups. Table 7 shows Contribution of NTFPs extracted from common property to total household gross income based on wealth group.

Title: Effects of participatory forest management on livelihood capitals of the community in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh
Author_affil: Laboratory of Global Forest Environmental Studies, Department of Global Agricultural Sciences, Graduate School of Global Agriculture and Life Sciences, The University of Tokyo
Funding: University Grants Commission of Bangladesh
Stated_int: Participatory forest management
Desired_out: "The projects studied were aimed at poor forest-dependent people in engaging in PF to improve their livelihoods and consequently to reduce the forest destruction." "The Forest Department in CoxÍs Bazar followed the interval of 2 m 9 2 m for planting trees in PF project areas. Each participant was allotted a 1- or 2-ha plantation under the PF program based on land availability. Rotation of the plantation was fixed as 10 years by the Forest Department. After the final harvest, each participant will receive 45 % of the total return of their allotted plantation. The Forest Department will receive 45 % of the final return as the cost of management of the plantation. And the remaining part of the return (i.e., 10 %) will be deposited in a tree farming fund (TFF) for the next term of plantations. But other returns such as fuel wood, litter, or products from intermediate tending operations were enjoyed solely by the participants"
Study_goal: "this research was attempted to analyze the effects of PF on the livelihood capital of the participants in CoxÍs Bazar."
Study_location: 21Á350 000 N and 92Á010 000 E (Dulahazara Beat of Fashiakhali Range and Fulchari Beat of Fulchari Range in CoxÍs Bazar North Forest Division, and Panerchar Beat of Panerchara Range and Khuniapalong Beat of Khuniap- along Range in CoxÍs Bazar South Forest Division - Cox's Bazar district)
Stated_outcomes: Income sources, human capital, physical capital, financial capital, natural capital, social capital

Desired_out: Protect lemur habitat. Linked projects to establish ecotourism and economic rural development, improve health, conservation education and conduct biodiversity research. Health care interventions intended to provide treatment of basic illnesses, health education, preventive care (vaccines, family planning, sanitation, health centers)
Study_goal: The main objective of the study is to examine the possible change in reproductive health, as measured by the onset of reproductive life, fertility, modern contraceptive use, birth conditions, prenatal health care and infant mortality. Title: Does ïïParticipationÍÍ in Common Pool Resource Management Help the Poor? A Social Cost_Benefit Analysis of Joint Forest Management in Jharkhand, India
Author_affil: University of Cambridge, UK
Funding: Society for Promotion of Wastelands Development, New Delhi
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management (JFM), Village Forest Committee (VFC)
Desired_out: "In a follow-up document issued in 1990, Central government issued guidelines to all State governments to implement ïïjoint forest management systems in order to regenerate forests and reduce rural poverty.... These guidelines suggested that the State governments may devolve everyday forest protection, management and development responsibilities to local community institutions (co-operative or committee-based) at the village or panchayat levels, 8 and prescribe benefit-sharing arrangements following regeneration"
Study_goal: "The paper begins with a description of IndiaÍs forest problems and policies, and a more specific account of the assumptions about ïïcommunityÍÍ and ïïrural povertyÍÍ that inform the agendas of Joint Forest Management (Section 2). Section 3 describes the patterns of community stratification and forest use in the study area, and in Section 4 the assumptions that underpin the social cost_benefit model are reviewed. Section 5 presents the main findings. It concludes that nonpoor members of VFCs determine the social time preference of JFM. It also shows how the management regimes for JFM forests that are put into place by VFCs must discriminate against the poor, often to a debilitating extent. Section 6 highlights the need for a more comprehensive SCBA that would take into account the value of local ecological services from JFM forests."
Study_location: Sarsa, Kelende, Bisa, Sadma, Banadag, Saheda, Tengariya, Bargainbanda villages - Ranchi District, Jharkhand State
Stated_outcomes: Change in costs and benefits to households from forests under JFM versus those not under JFM, Number of trees

Title: A comparative analysis of the effects of institutional property rights on forest livelihoods and forest conditions: Evidence from Ghana and Vietnam
Author_affil: BayCEER, Bayreuth University, Universitaetstr. 30, 95440 Bayreuth, Germany
Stated_int: Forest institutional property rights
Desired_out: "Effective and robust forest institutional property rights are increasingly becoming an important part on the allocation of scarce forest resources and a solution to the ñtragedy of the commonsî"
Study_goal: "The main motivation of this study is our need to understand the role of institutions, property rights on livelihoods in a forestry context and examine the connectivity of these three concepts. This need has a theoretical offset hence our attempt to operationalise using a broad framework for conceptualisation. This is addressed by answering the following explicit three questions: (1) what is the ñstate of the artî literature on institutional property rights in re- source management? This helps in the decomposition of property rights linkages on livelihoods and forest conditions; (2) how to comparatively evaluate these property rights effects on livelihoods and forest conditions as outcomes in an empirical micro level?; and (3) how to integrate these findings into building models for sustainable future design of forest insti- tutional property rights arrangements?"
Study_location: Vietnam, Ghana
Stated_outcomes: Change in livelihoods, change in forest conditions, change in access

Funding: The pilot certification project was technically and financially supported through a broad multinational Private Public Alliance (PPA), coordinated by ANSAB. Partners of the PPA were community forest user groups, the Federation of Community Forestry Users of Nepal (FECOFUN), environmental non-governmental organizations (NGO) from the United States (US) of America (The Rainforest Alliance, (RA)) and from Nepal, representatives of the Nepali government, private companies dealing in environmental products (e.g. Aveda(TM) and Nepali companies), and donor organizations (The Ford Foundation, the Netherlands Development Organization (SNV) and the US Agency for International Development (USAID).
