Title: Rural household income and inequality under the Sloping Land Conversion Program in western China
Journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Author_affil: Institute of Population and Development Studies, School of Public Policy and Administration, Xian Jiaotong University, XiÍan, Shaanxi Province 710049, China
Funding: China National Natural Science Fund (70773094), the Program for Changjiang Scholars and Innovative Research Team in University (PCSIRT 0855), the Natural Capital Project (a partnership among Stanford University, The Nature Conservancy, the World Wildlife Fund, and the University of Minnesota), and the Morrison Institute for Population and Resource Studies at Stanford University
Stated_int: Sloping Land Conversion Program, Payments for Ecosystem Services
Desired_out: "The SLCP provides farmers with grain and cash subsidies in exchange for converting cropland on steep slopes to much less erodible forest and grassland." "The Chinese government aims to reduce the loss of soil, improve water retention, and generally protect bio- diversity and ecosystems in the west of the country for flood control, hydropower production efficiency, and ecotourism. In addition, it wants to change the economic structure in mountainous areas to increase local household income while simultaneously making local householdsÍ patterns of land utilization and agricultural production more sustainable"
Study_goal: "This paper focuses on a remote rural area in western China where the SLCP has been enforced since 2000. We first introduce the study area, the sampling method, the analytical framework, and methods and then assess the impacts of SLCP on rural household incomes, and inequality among these households, us- ing data and information from interviews and a survey."
Study_location: 15 vilages in Zhouzhi County, Xi'an Shaanxi Province
Stated_outcomes: Income levels from different sources, income inequality

Title: Are We Getting There? Evidence of Decentralized Forest Management from the Tanzanian Miombo Woodlands
Author_affil: University of Copenhagen, Frederiksberg, Denmark
Funding: The Danish Council for Development Research, O.H.F. and A.J.-E. Heilmanns Fond, and Oticon Fonden
Stated_int: Decentralized forest management, MEMA projects
Desired_out: Transferring rights to and powers over forest resources to locally democratically elected bodies. Danida-funded MEMA Projects - villages "received support to initiate awareness campaigns in the village, delineate and demarcate its village land and forest reserve boundaries, formulate a forest management plan, and begin managing its village land forest reserve (VLFR). While delimitating the VLFR, open access to other woodland areas, where the majority of villagers gather firewood, was deliberately maintained."
Int_dur: Policies enacted 1995-2003, national program from 2003 onwards
Study_goal: "Drawing on several months of field work over four years in Mfyome village, South-western Tanzania, we will present the outcomes of a recent forest decentralization process. First, we present the case study context and methods. Second, the current outcome of decentralized forest man- agement is presented in terms of effects on (i) resource conservation, (ii) rural livelihoods, and (iii) good governance."
Study_location: Matembo and Msosa sub-village in Mfyome village
Stated_outcomes: Difference in forest income between wealth quartiles, access to markets, access to land

Authors: Ly N

outcome.Indicators: effect of participating in the PFES pilot on annual household income
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: Findings show a VND 3.95 million positive impact of program participation on annual household income. Although the T-value has increased to 1.34, the result is not significant at the 10% level of significance. This means that PFES participation did not have a significant impact on annual household income during the pilot period if we consider the difference in annual income between participants and non-participants. However, after iterations for PS matching techniques and the DID method, the results show that participation in the PFES program during the pilot period has approximately a positive impact of VND 3.9 million on household annual income, and this impact is significant at the 5% level. It was not significant at the 10% level though.

Title: Evaluating the Pilot Implementation of Payment for Forest Environmental Services in Lam Dong, Vietnam
Author_affil: Department of Environmental and Natural Resource Economics, Faculty of Economics, University of Agriculture and Forestry (UAF), Linh Trung Ward, Thu Duc District, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
Funding: The Economy and Environment Program for Southeast Asia (EEPSEA)
Stated_int: Pilot payment for forest environmental services (PFES) policy in Lam Dong Province, Vietnam. In April 2008, the Vietnam government issued Decision no. 380/Q_-TTg to implement payment for forest environmental services nationwide. The policy aims to make PFES compulsory in Vietnam, but it was first piloted for a two-year period in Lam Dong and Son La provinces. Experiences and lessons learned in the Vietnamese context were used to build a national policy (2011 onwards).
Desired_out: Ecosystem conservation, livelihood improvements
Study_goal: This study aims to assess the performance and the short-term impacts of the payment for forest environmental services (PFES) policy in Lam Dong Province, Vietnam. Economic and environmental impacts were evaluated by estimating the changes in local income, forest area, amount of illegal logging, and forest density/quality since the program was implemented.
Study_location: Study focuses on the implementation of the policy in four piloted zones: three districts _ Lac Duong, Don Duong, Duc Trong _ and Da Lat City.
Study_duration: Households had participated in the PES up to December 2010
Stated_outcomes: Effect of participating in the PFES pilot on various economic and environmental variables.

Title: Booming markets for Moroccan argan oil appear to benefit some rural households while threatening the endemic argan forest
Author_affil: Agricultural and Resource Economics, University of California, Davis, CA 95616
Stated_int: MoroccoÍs argan oil is now the most expensive edible oil in the world. High-value argan markets have sparked a bonanza of argan activity.
Desired_out: Nongovernmental organizations, international and domestic development agencies, and argan oil cooperatives aggressively promote the win_win aim of simultaneously benefiting local people and the health of the argan forest.
Int_dur: Since 1999, rapidly appreciating prices in high-value markets have sparked a bonanza of argan activity.
Study_goal: Win_win claims of poverty alleviation and biodiversity conservation now appear on virtually every argan product label and have been showcased by media outlets worldwide. Using a combination of household- and landscape-level analyses, we evaluate these now common argan claims.
Study_location: Essaouira Province
Study_duration: Survey conducted in 1999 and again in 2007
Stated_outcomes: Three types of household welfare outcomes: consumption (spending at market), assets (livestock holdings), and childrenÍs education
Stated_mech: Forest products often function as an important safety net by helping vulnerable households cope with hard times and thereby, may prevent households from slipping farther into poverty, but it may be difficult for such households to leverage forest products as a means of accumulating the assets needed to shift to higher-return pursuits. Furthermore, even the safety net benefit can be compromised if commercialization depletes forest resources, leaving vulnerable households more susceptible to adverse shocks that can drive them deeper into poverty.

Title: Improving the bene ts to the poor from community forestry in the Churia region of Nepal
Author_affil: CARE Nepal, Krishna Galli, Patan, P.O. Box 1661, Kathmandu, Nepal
Funding: Output from an action research project conducted by CARE Nepal with support of CARE International, CARE Austria, CARE Denmark, the Overseas Development Institute (ODI) and Ford Foundation.
Stated_int: Community forestry, community forest user groups
Desired_out: "Introduce programmes specially designed to increase the wellbeing of the poor, vulnerable and socially excluded people living in these areas"
Study_goal: "The Nepal research was conducted in 2006-7 by CARE Nepal to understand and improve the livelihood impacts of community forestry in the Churia, Bhawar and Terai regions. The research was designed to answer several basic questions: 1. Can community forestry contribute to poverty reduction or livelihood improvement by providing rural people with a sustainable stream of net benefits greater than those obtained under a non-community forestry situation? 2. How significant are the benefits of community forestry for different wellbeing groups? What are the key negative impacts of community forestry and on whom do they fall? 3. What characteristics of community forestry determine its impacts (both positive and negative) on poverty and equity?"
Study_location: Central region (Sarlahi district - Ramjanaki, Pasupati; Mahotari district- Musahar, Ratu Mahila, Phuljour), Mid-western region (Bardia district - Sati, Srijana Mahila; Banke district - Srijana, Jharana, Gabar)
Stated_outcomes: Financial capital, physical capital, human capital, natural capital, social capital, political capital

Title: The Impact of Participatory Forest Management on Local Community Livelihoods in the Arabuko_Sokoke Forest, Kenya
Author_affil: Nature Kenya, Nairobi, Kenya
Funding: Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB)
Stated_int: Participatory forest management, community forestry, butterfly farming, Arabuko-Sokeke community forest
Desired_out: "The main objective of the butterfly farming project was to reduce pre-colonial and post-colonial negativity among the local people by providing incentives for local communities to support forest conservation objectives"
Study_goal: "This study assesses the impact of participatory forest management on the household livelihoods of residents near the Arabuko-Sokoke forest and answers the following questions: 1) does forest conservation result in net benefits to local communities living adjacent to the forest?; 2) does participatory forest management (PFM) enhance net incomes to forest-adjacent households in the Arabuko-Sokoke forest?; and 3) are household benefits uniformly distributed within the 5 km intervention zone? The hypotheses tested by the study are: 1) forest conservation benefits exceed forest conservation costs; 2) PFM areas have higher benefits compared to areas without PFM; and 3) benefits and costs reduce with distance from forest edge."
Study_location: Arabuko-Sokoke forest
Stated_outcomes: Conservation costs (livestock predation, livestock loss, crop damage), forest benefits (firewood extraction, herbal medicine, building materials, NTFPs, employment)

Title: Does Adaptive Collaborative Forest Governance Affect Poverty? Participatory Action Research in NepalÍs Community Forests
Author_affil: Department of Communication and Innovation Studies, Wageningen University, Wageningen, The Netherlands
Funding: the Asian Development Bank and CanadaÍs International Development Research Centre (IDRC), and the complementary funders, Center for International Forestry Research, the Consultative Group on International Agricultural ResearchÍs System wide Programme on Participatory Research and Gender Analysis, the International Institute for Rural Reconstruction, and Local Initiatives for Biodiversity, Research and Development, Nepal
Stated_int: Community forestry
Desired_out: "NepalÍs Community Forestry Program has been widely implemented since its inception in the late 1980s. It was established out of concern regarding deforestation and environmental degradation." "...two of the programÍs key second-generation challenges are to increase the level of livelihood benefits and their distributional equity"
Study_goal: "To what extent do CFUGs prioritize and meet the needs of women and the poor? What is the influence of adaptive collaborative governance of community forests on the generation and distribution of subsistence and income-related benefits, especially for women and the poor? How do the various elements of an adaptive collaborative approach have such an influence? And, in broader terms, what insights does the research suggest in terms of the conceptualization of poverty alleviation, including the significance of internal power relations?"
Study_location: Kaski district (Bamdibhir, Deurali Bagedanda), Sankhuwasabha district (Andheribhajana, Manakamana, Pathivara), Palpa district (Kajipauwa), Nawalparasi (Chautari), Lalitpur district (Patle), Dhankuta district (Handikharka, Khanuyubas Salleri), Morang district (Chautari)
Stated_outcomes: Changes in CFUG rules affecting distributional equity, changes income generation activities and loans, employment

Title: Transaction costs of community-based forest management: empirical evidence from Tanzania
Author_affil: Tanzania Forest Conservation Group, PO Box 23410, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania
Funding: CARE _ Norway through the Misitu Yetu Project, a partnership project between Tanzania Forest Conservation Group (TFCG), CARE _ Tanzania and Wildlife Conservation of Tanzania (WCST)
Stated_int: Community-based forest management
Desired_out: "Through joint forest management with communities, the district government and the Ambangulu Tea Estate, the Tanzania Forest Conservation Group (TFCG) is leading the process to protect this important site... The key management activities carried out include monitoring through patrolling, provision of extension services, alternative sources of forest resources and facilitation of forest management plans and by-law development."
Study_goal: "To explore this issue further, a study was carried out to assess transaction costs and to obtain estimates of net benefits of CBFM in four communities adjacent to a single area of forest. The study had three objectives. First, to identify costs and benefits of community forest management to the rich, middle and poor groups of users. Second, to quantify costs and benefits for these subgroups based on prevailing economic conditions. Third, to assess the comparative flow of benefits and costs for each income group. The overall aim of the study was to contribute to the understanding of transaction costs in CBFM and make suggestions for more equitable community forest management practices in Tanzania."
Study_location: Ambangulu forest, West Usambara mountains (5Á09'S, 38Á45'E)
Stated_outcomes: Transaction costs incurred from PFM, forest benefits from CBFM, food security, perception of impact of PFM

Title: Forest-dependent communitiesÍ livelihood in decentralized forest governance policy epoch: case study from West Shoa zone, Ethiopia
Journal: Journal of Natural Resources Policy Research
Author_affil: Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences, The University of Tokyo 1-1-1 Yayoi, Bunkyo, Tokyo 113-8657, Japan
Funding: Grants-in-Aid for Scientific Research (A) from the Government of Japan (No. 19208014, project leader: Makoto Inoue)
Stated_int: Decentralized forest governance, devolution form of decentralization, delegation form of decentralization, peasant associations
Desired_out: "Devolution and delegation are among the major forms of decentralization that are currently being undertaken in the forestry sector of the country. Under delegation, all forest governance decision-making power, that is, that for forest management, protection, and utilization, is delegated to the Forest and Wildlife Enterprise. On the other hand, under devolution, the decision-making power to manage and protect the forest is devolved to forest user groups (which later became cooperatives)."
Study_goal: "By examining communities in or near forests that are managed by the delegation and the devolution forms of decentralization, this paper aims to fill the aforementioned research gap with the following two objectives: to identify important types of capital for local peoplesÍ livelihood as a coping mechanism from vulnerabilities and as a source of income and to investigate the impact of delegation and devolution forms of forest governance on the capital."
Study_location: Jibat forest (Tutu peasant's association), Chilimo forest (Gare Arera peasant association)
Study_duration: September and October 2011 and January and February 2012
Stated_outcomes: Change in forest-based capital, non-forest based capital, and human capital

Title: THE ROLE OF PARTICIPATORY SOCIAL FORESTRY IN THE ENHANCEMENT OF THE SOCIO-ECONOMIC CONDITION OF THE RURAL POOR: A CASE STUDY OF DHAKA FOREST DIVISION IN BANGLADESH
Author_affil: Forest Policy Laboratory, Department of Forest Science, Faculty of Agriculture, Shinshu University, 8304 Minamiminowa - mura, 399 - 4598 Nagano - ken, Japan.
Funding: The authors also acknowledge JSPS authority of Japan for sponsoring the research fund.
Stated_int: Social forestry program in Bangladesh
Desired_out: Social forestry is an umbrella term broadly associated with practicing forestry activities involving local people and other relevant stakeholders as active partner under a legal frame work of benefit sharing in order to improve the forests, micro -environment and socio-economic condition of the local poor. In this type of participatory forestry programme, the local people as programme beneficiaries provide their off-farm family labour. All other management inputs and technical supports are provided by the government. Here the main objectives are to integrate the people in this programme to ensure better plantation protection and to help them to find an alternative source of income to eradicate their poverty. At the same time, the local people who used to be treated as encroacher of forests and forest resources, are motivated to stop their destruction of the forest. As a result of their off farm family labour they are active beneficiaries of the programme. Generally three types of short rotation plantation are being raised under the social forestry programme viz. woodlot plantations, agroforestry plantings, and strip plantations. The Forestry Department aimed to raise the benefits from woodlots and strip planting above those of the agroforestry plots.
Int_dur: Participatory social forestry was introduced in Bangladesh in early 1980s
Study_goal: This explorative research, based on case study analysis, was conducted to assess the role of participatory social forestry on enhancement of socio-economic condition of the grass root level people in Bangladesh.
Study_location: Dhaka Forest Division, which lies to three civil districts viz. Dhaka, Gazipur, and Narayanganj.
Study_duration: A randomly selected subset of beneficiaries who raised woodlots, agroforestry plantations and strip plantations in 1992 and felled them in 2004 were included in the analysis.
Stated_outcomes: Financial gains (income) of program participants

Title: Forest-based settlement project and its impacts on community livelihood in the chittagong hill tracts, Bangladesh
Author_affil: Institute of Forestry and Environmental Sciences, University of Chittagong , Chittagong; Department of Global Agricultural Sciences, Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences, The University of Tokyo
Stated_int: Upland Settlement Project (participatory forestry)
Desired_out: A participatory forestry (PF) project known as the Upland Settlement Project (USP) initiated in the the early 1980s in degraded forest areas of the Chittangong Hill Tracts. The USP has rehabilitated landless jhumias, through a number of agroforestry and social development functions including capacity-building and infrastructure development.
Study_goal: "The present study was a comprehensive livelihood analyses based on a sustainable livelihood (SL) framework and examined five types of livelihood capitals - namely human, physical, natural, financial, and social capital - of the participants, as well as the factors that underlay success or failure of the settlement project in achieving targeted project's objectives and livelihood diversification strategies."

Stated_outcomes: Human capital, physical capital, natural capital, financial capital, groups and networks, trust and solidarity

Title: Lessons about parks and poverty from a decade of forest loss and economic growth around Kibale National Park, Uganda
Journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Author_affil: Department of Geography, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706;
Funding: Grant 98-10144 from the Geography and Regional Science Division of the National Science Foundation, grants from Princeton University and the University of Wisconsin at Madison, Conservation International, Fulbright, the Canada Research Chairs Program, the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada, and US Agency for International Development Translinks Agreement EPP-A-00-06-00014-00
Stated_int: Kibale National Park
Desired_out: "After Kibale became a park in 1993..." focusing on biodiversity conservation. ...."timber extraction, hunting, charcoal production, and agriculture were curtailed, although local people have continued to draw nontimber forest products (NTFPs) from the park"
Study_goal: "This paper examines the relationship between forest use, biodiversity loss, and poverty. In particular, it considers whether park restrictions on forest use induce a poverty trap..." "We test whether proximity to a forest park is a key geographic characteristic promoting the emergence or continuation of a poverty trap. In addition, we compare local citizensÍ use of forest in KNP vs. adjacent communal forest patches where commercial extraction is allowed. We also compare forest use by the poorest households with that of their more affluent counterparts."
Study_location: 8 villages around Kibale National Park
Stated_outcomes: Forest use and cover change, household welfare change over time, wealth outcomes over groups, time, and distance

Title: Community forestry in, the Mayan Biosphere Reserve in Guatemala. Journal of Sustainable Forestry, 19(4): and 11-28.
Author_affil: Muhlenberg College, Allentown, PA 18104-5586 USA
Funding: USAID, the Moriah Fund, and The Rodale Institute
Stated_int: Bethel cooperative in buffer zone of Mayan Biosphere Reserve (a Man and Biosphere site). Managed under polycyclic felling system. Ecotourism, locally production, and NTFP collection and sales.
Desired_out: Establishment of reserve in 1990 to protect forest ecosystems and facilitate coexistence between communities and ecosystems (under Man and Biosphere). Bethel cooperative established in 1994 as part of effort to sustainably harvest timber from around reserve area for economic development and support conservation agenda. Bethel cooperative forest is managed under polycyclic felling system with other techniques designed to encourage regeneration. Locally mill timber and produce furniture, establish ecotourism, income from non-timber sources.
Study_goal: "In this paper, we provide an early assessment of a forestry program in the Bethel cooperative in Northern Guatemala that is located in the buffer zone of the Mayan Biosphere Reserve (MBR), a MAB site. Our objectives are to assess the initial impact of harvest on forest structure and natural regeneration, and to predict the potential for sustained timber production under current harvest practice. We also provide some data to indicate whether increased community regulated forestry resulted in increased income for the current population"
Stated_outcomes: Income from community forest management, income from NTFPs, Income from furniture making, ecotourism

Title: The effects of markets on the use of forest for the livelihood of indigenous households in the Colombian Amazon
Author_affil: OMACHA Foundation; Centre for Biological and Cultural Conservation. Leticia, Amazonas, Colombia.
Funding: This work was carried out with the aid of a research grant from the Latin American and Caribbean Environmental Economics Program (LACEEP, www.laceep.org).
Stated_int: Expansion of markets/difference in geographical access to markets?
Desired_out: It is not clear
Int_dur: Paper discusses various changes over the past 20 years: Over the past 20 years, the region has faced several social and economical transformations. Traditional people have changed their livelihood strategies. Economic activities including rubber extraction, cattle ranching, and cocaine processing have had a major impact in the region (Hammond et al., 1995). Development programs and rural extension programs have introduced cash crops suitable for export and have encouraged people to increase agricultural production. In more recent years, the indigenous population has broadly increased its interaction with external markets, adopting alternative forms of production and resource management oriented towards the generation of cash income.
Study_goal: This paper presents results from research conducted in the Colombian Amazon. We report findings from two main issues: First, the use of forest for income generation among indigenous societies, and second, the associations between total household income and the use of forest products for livelihood purposes.
Study_location: The research was conducted in the Colombian Amazonian district (Figure 1). The region is located at the left-hand side of the map below, along the stretch of the Amazon River between Iquitos (Peru) and Tabatinga (Brazil). The territory includes 48 indigenous villages from different ethnic groups settled along 117 km on the bank of the Amazon river (3Á4 S, 69_3 W, 70_ 4 E).
Stated_outcomes: Use of forest for cash and subsistence; Dependence on environmental incomes
Portion_livelihood_amount: Forest and agroforestry together provide 60% of total household income and 50% of cash earnings.

Title: Beyond the Decade of Policy and Community Euphoria: The State of Livelihoods Under New Local Rights to Forest in Rural Cameroon
Author_affil: Africa Program, Rights and Resources Initiative, Washington, DC
Funding: This research benefited from funding from the International Development Research Centre, and the Ford Foundation.
Linked_refs: This paper is derived from a strategic study conducted by the Center for International Forestry Research in Cameroon in 2007 and 2008 (see Larson and Dahal This issue)
Stated_int: Allocation of new community rights to local forests, forest resources, and benefits associated with their commercial exploitation in Cameroon
Desired_out: Preservation of the resource base/improved livelihoods
Int_dur: Since 1993/1994: The provisional Zoning Plan of the forested Cameroon, developed in 1993, and the Forestry Legislation of 1994 are the founding legal instruments for the reorganisation of the structure of the bundle of community rights to forests and resources.
Study_goal: This study seeks to assess the effects of the allocation of new community rights to local forests, forest resources, and benefits associated with their commercial exploitation. The Cameroon research upon which this paper is based was guided by the following hypotheses: 'securing community rights to forests ensures the security of the resource base'; 'the transfer of community tenure rights is synonymous with improved livelihoods'; 'securing and improving livelihoods increases monetary income and contributes to poverty reduction'; and 'securing community tenure rights leads to forest sustainability'.
Study_location: Four research sites located in the forested Cameroon were selected for this research, namely, Lomi_/Dja area (east region), Ocean area (south region), Mount Cameroon area (southwest region) and Mount Oku area (northwest region).
Study_duration: The assessment is conducted over a period of 10 years-i.e., from the end of the 1990s to the end of the 2000s
Stated_outcomes: Access to schools/health facilities before and after reforms. Community income before and after reforms.

Title: A triple win? The impact of TanzaniaÍs Joint Forest Management programme on livelihoods, governance and forests
Author_affil: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, US Department of Geography and Curriculum for Ecology and the Environment
Funding: Funding for this impact evaluation was provided by 3ieÍs donors, which include UK aid, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Hewlett Foundation and 12 other 3ie members that provide institutional support. A complete listing is provided on the 3ie website at http://www.3ieimpact.org/en/about/3ie-affiliates/3ie-members/
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management
Desired_out: Core objectives are: (1) restoring forests, (2) improving livelihoods, and (3) strengthening local governance
Study_goal: The overarching goals of this impact evaluation of TanzaniaÍs JFM are to: (1) determine JFMÍs average impacts on its stated goals of improved village governance, household livelihoods, and forest conditions; (2) understand if and how JFM impacts poorer villages and the poorest households within villages differently from other villages and households; and (3) draw on our study findings to generate policy-relevant recommendations for how JFM might be modified or better targeted to meet its goals more effectively.
Study_location: 7 regions of eastern Tanzania: Kilimanjaro, Tanga, Pwani, Lindi, Morogoro, Iringa, Mbeya

Desired_out: Using bottom-up participatory approach, form forest user groups with elected management boards to develop and implement forest management plans in compliance regulations from government. All four villages put a strong emphasis on (i) forest protection by strict control on harvest of timber and non-timber forest products, (ii) development of degraded forest caused by shifting cultivation by enrichment planting and plantation establishment, (iii) establishment of a community development fund (CDF), and (iv) benefit sharing.

outcome.Indicators: The outcomevariables are 1) food security; 2) the household income in Bhutanese Ngultrum; 3) food poverty.
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: The average treatment affect for the treated (ATT) are Ngultrum 2605_3169 higher for the participating households as compared to non-participating households.  The results for food poverty indicate that households participating in the community forest program have lower poverty levels in the range of 5_12 percentage points than those who do not participate. From the empirical results, it can be concluded that community participation in forest management can help to increase the household income and can also help to reduce poverty in the range of 5_12 percentage points. The food security levels were high in the range of 12%_19% because, the communities were deriving a number of benefits such as fruit, vegetables and nuts, etc., from the program.

Title: Household participation and effects of community forest management on income and poverty levels: Empirical evidence from Bhutan
Author_affil: Socioeconomics Program, International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT), 10 Km. 45, Carretera Mex-Veracruz, El Batan, Mexico
Stated_int: Community-based forest management
Desired_out: Sustainable resource management, improved livelihoods
Int_dur: Initially, the CF was started cautiously with the establishment of the first CFs in Eastern Bhutan in the late 1990s
Study_goal: The objectives of the present study are to (1) identify and analyze the factors influencing household participation in community forest management programs, and (2) assess the effects of community participation in forest management on household income and poverty levels in Bhutan.
Study_location: Across the whole country
Stated_outcomes: Determinants of household participation in community forest management; Impact of community forest management on income, household food security and poverty levels

Title: Impacts of Trade in Non-timber Forest Products on Cooperation among Caboclo Households of the Brazilian Amazon
Author_affil: Programa de PÑs-graduaçÜo em Ciência Ambiental, Universidade de SÜo Paulo
Funding: Kleinhans Award (Rainforest Alliance), scholarship from FAPESP (Brazil) to Rizek (Processo: 2007/06844-5)
Stated_int: Trade agreement between communities and companies
Desired_out: The trade agreement involved the two companies (Natura and Cognis) and CODAEMJ, for participating residents to collect and sell NTFPs to companies. Participation involved paying an annual fee, which guaranteed access to a share of the profits. Community members received payments for NTFP gathering and selling to the cooperative, participation in purchasing trips, local transportation of seeds to the processing plant, seed breaking and selection, temporary employment in the processing plant, and permanent employment for managing the processing plant and the relationship with the companies.
Study_goal: To evaluate the effects of involvement in the NTFP market on cooperation among households
Study_location: Roque, Pupuai in Medio Jurua Extractive Reserve, Carauari town, Amazonas State
Stated_outcomes: Obtaining goods and income via cooperation

Title: Maintaining the contract responsibility system of forest land distribution in China: Evidence from a novel financial compensation scheme in Daxi Village of Anji County, Zhejiang
Author_affil: Department of Ecology, Autonomous University of Madrid, Darwin Street 2, Cantoblanco 28049, Madrid, Spain
Funding: AECI (Spanish International Cooperation Agency) and Mutua Madrilena de Seguros
Stated_int: Inter-household Forest Compensation Scheme
Desired_out: "This compensation scheme revolves around an equal-per-capita land access principle which, being the cornerstone of the HRS and CRS across Rural China, shaped householdsÍ forest endowments at the onset of post-78 reforms in our study area. At its core, the scheme brings up the new notion of redistributing a certain amount of the communityÍs forest production, compensating those households with increased family size but without curtailing private forest entrepreneurship."
Study_goal: "We analyze the evolution of the Inter-household Forest Compensation Scheme, its impact in local and household economies, and farmersÍ attitudes and opin- ions about the effectiveness and fairness of the system. Our aim is to better understand the interactions that occur between land rightsÍ institutions and forest management, as a contribution to the literature on rural land reform and particularly focused on forest redistributive practices in China."
Study_location: Anji County, Daxi Village
Stated_outcomes: Percent compensation, per capita income, perceptions of compensation benefits

Title: Tracking outcomes of social capital and institutional innovations in natural resources management: Methodological issues and empirical evidence from participatory bylaw reform in Uganda
Author_affil: International Development Research Centre , Nairobi, Kenya
Stated_int: Participatory learning and action research (PLAR) project, natural resource management
Desired_out: "A 5-year (2000_2004) participatory learning and action research (PLAR) project that aimed at strengthening social capital for improved policies and decision making in natural resource management." "The main thrust of the project was that rural communities and local stakeholders would be more likely to implement policies and bylaws if they had participated in their formulation. The projectÍs strategy was to build on existing social capital and to strengthen it through the facilitation of participatory social learning and policy dialogue processes aimed at building ïïadaptive manager communities,ÍÍ communities that are empowered to deal with policies and other drivers of change and possess institutions for social learning"
Study_goal: "In this article we use empirical evidence from a tracking study to investigate the outcomes and potential impacts of a 5-year participatory learning and action research (PLAR) project that aimed at strengthening the capacity of local communities to formulate and implement bylaws for sustainable NRM. This tracking study was undertaken one year after the end of the PLAR project to investigate and document the specific outcomes, potential impacts, and conditions for sustainability of strengthened social capital for improving policies and decision making in NRM."
Study_location: Kabale district
Stated_outcomes: Conflict between households/wildlife, female participation, cooperation between households, cohesion between community

Title: Why May Forest Devolution Not Benefit the Rural Poor Forest Entitlements in VietnamÍs Central Highlands

Stated_int: Forest devolution, forestland allocation

Title: Subsidies for Rubber: Conserving Rainforests While Sustaining Livelihoods in the Amazon?
Author_affil: Department of Forestry and Environmental Resources, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, North Carolina, USA
Funding: the Ford Foundation, IMAZON, and North Carolina State University
Stated_int: Rubber subsidies, Rubber program (Programa de Desenvolvimento da Cadeia Produtiva da Borracha), extractive reserves
Desired_out: "The immediate goal of the subsidy is to improve the living standards of rubber tappers, which in turn is expected to reduce deforestation both by encouraging rubber tappers to stay in the forest, thus preventing invasion by ranchers and farmers; and by encouraging rubber tappers to focus on rubber, rather than expanding into agriculture and cattle"
Study_goal: "We use these data to describe the distribution of the subsidy, including which associations and rubber tappers participated in the program and how payments were distributed across rubber tappers, associations, and municipalities."
Study_location: Acre state
Stated_outcomes: Number of families benefiting from rubber subsidy, sale of cattle

Authors: Sims K, Alix-Garcia J

outcome.Indicators: Change in the poverty alleviation index: based on area-weighted means of the locality marginality index from 1990 and 2000
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: With respect to development goals, the data show that PES led to small but statistically significant poverty alleviation - a 10-12% increase in the local poverty alleviation index. Parks as a group had no effect on locality poverty trends, although strict protected areas showed significantly less poverty alleviation than the counterfactual trend. Importantly, none of the park types or PES increased poverty according to absolute measures: localities with conservation policies showed improvements on average across all basic poverty indicators.

Journal: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management

Stated_outcomes: Changes in the locality level poverty alleviation index from 2000_2010

Title: Distributing conservation incentives in the buffer zone of Chitwan National Park, Nepal
Author_affil: Alberta Tourism, Parks, Recreation and Culture, PO Box 280, Exshaw, Alberta, Canada T0L 2C0; 26-640 Upper Lakeview Road, Invermere, BC Canada, V0A 1K3
Funding: the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (Grant No. 410-2003-0136), research support from Damodar Khadka, Jeremy Mackenzie, Ray Chipeniuk and Gail Fondhal
Stated_int: Incentive-based programs, Chitwan National Park, buffer zone management incl. ecotourism and community forestry
Desired_out: "The buffer zone was established in 1996 in response to the need for landscape-scale conservation and to address the conflicts between communities and the Park ... The DNPWC and its non-government partners have since initiated programmes to support conservation within and around CNP and improve the economic conditions for local people. Buffer zone projects have included capacity building through training, Park infrastructure improvements, revenue sharing and community forestry."
Study_goal: "This paper examines the IBPs applied in the buffer zone of CNP based on local residentsÍ perceptions of IBP benefits. The main objectives are to (1) examine local residentsÍ perceived costs due to PA management, and perceived benefits from IBPs around the CNP and (2) evaluate the CNPÍs ability to focus the distribution of benefits on those most affected by the ParkÍs conservation efforts"
Study_location: Chitwan National Park
Stated_outcomes: Perceived benefits from ecotourism to economy, employment, social development, conservation, mitigation and participation

Title: Poverty alleviation as a pathway to sustainable forest management
Author_affil: Tamil Nadu Forest Department, 1- Jeenis Road, Chennai 600015, India
Funding: The study forms part of the first authorÍs PhD dissertation work.
Stated_int: Tamil Nadu Afforestation Project (TAP)
Desired_out: TAP focused on poverty alleviation as the principal means to achieve sustainable forest management. TAP placed emphasis on providing alternative livelihood opportunities, encouraging micro-finance institutions through self-help groups, and promoting capacity building through systematic institutional development
Int_dur: TAP initiated in the state in 1997.
Study_goal: This study endeavours to provide insights into the effectiveness of the TAPÍs strategy of ensuring sustainable forest management through poverty alleviation and community development. An in-depth analysis of information on selected ecological and socio-economic indicators provides the basis for drawing conclusions. Elaborating on the opportunities and challenges entailed in the TAP strategy, the paper also discusses the role of developing appropriate institutional mechanisms to integrate conservation and development efforts from practitionersÍ perspective, to enable participatory forest management to succeed.
Study_location: Tamil Nadu: three TAP sites namely TN Pudukudi, Jothinagar, and Kannamoochi representing Western Ghats, Eastern Ghats, and a transition zone, respectively
Stated_outcomes: Changes in selected indicators of socio-economic development
Stated_mech: ...forests act as poor peopleÍs means to meet contingencies and reduce their vulnerability to risks...An estimated 41% of IndiaÍs forest cover has been degraded to some degree in the past and average forest productivity is about one-third of the potential. Rapid deterioration of forests thus deeply undermines the poor peopleÍs daily struggle to maintain living standards. The adverse effects of natural resources degradation reflect in reduced productivity, which ends up in enhanced poverty and misery.

outcome.Indicators: income earned from collecting NTFPs; PCA biplot analysis on differences across villages for livelihoods

This shows that the level of commercial forest dependency increases with decreasing accessibility.  Boxplot analysis showed that income is a strong factor differentiating the livelihood of households in village 1, and percentage of NTFP income in village 3. Village 2 is intermediate with respect to many variables. Income and land availability have significant correlation to each other but not with income from NTFPs and percentage of NTFP income.

Title: Secondary Forests and Local Livelihoods along a Gradient of Accessibility: A Case Study in Northern Laos
Author_affil: Centre for Development and Environment, University of Bern, Bern, Switzerland
Funding: Sincere thanks to all the officers of the National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute (NAFRI) and District Office of Forestry in Phonxay district who generously offered valuable help, support, and resources to facilitate the research. Financial support was received from the National Centre of Competence in Research (NCCR) North_South and from the Asian Institute of Technology (AIT).
Stated_int: Impact of increased accessibility on forests and forest livelihoods. Accessibility, in this study, refers mainly to physical or transportation accessibility, for example, better road condition.
Desired_out: By opening new market opportunities, accessibility improvement can reduce poverty and increase food security. However, resource degradation is also possible, such as where increased trade in NTFPs, leads to resource depletion.
Int_dur: N/A: Accessbility is an issue internationally for various time periods.
Study_goal: Focusing on forest condition and local livelihoods, this article leads to better understanding of the benefits and threats of improved accessibility, and of how internal factors such as forest dependency and external factors such as government influence and market accessibility interact with each other to produce these effects.
Study_location: We compare the conditions of secondary forests and local livelihoods of the villages of Nambor (village 1), Huay Lung Theung (village 2), and Na Ngiw (village 3) located along the secondary road leading from Luang Prabang to western Phonxay district in Luang Prabang province. Village 1 is 45 km from the provincial center, village 265 km, and village 3,115 km.
Study_duration: Field research was conducted from October to December 2007.
Stated_outcomes: Condition of secondary forests; impact of accessibility on local livelihoods (income earned from collecting NTFPs; PCA biplot analysis on differences across villages for livelihoods)
Portion_livelihood_amount: Study provides % of income from NTFPs/household for each village. This value ranges from 7.1% to 15% across the three villages.

Title: A survey-based evaluation of community-based co-management of forest resources: a case study of Baishuijiang National Natural Reserve in China
Author_affil: School of Environment, Resources and Development, Asian Institute of Technology, P.O. Box 4, Klong Luang Pathumthani, Bangkok 12120, Thailand
Funding: Asian Institution of Technology for doctoral student research
Stated_int: Community-based co-management, Baishujiang National Nature Reserve
Desired_out: "With the help of government officials and institution researchers, a group of development project applications with the aim of livelihood diversity and resource use substitution have been accepted by government agency or NGOs. These projects include firewood- saving cooking stoves, application of marsh gas pools, planting diverse species of trees or crops and providing a variety of agro-technical trainings."
Study_goal: "In this paper, we focus on how local villagers perceive the process and products of CBCM projects on their livelihood and identify changes in income and consumption that support the perceived impacts. Our goal is to reveal a more comprehensive and objective understanding about current CBCM mechanisms, to identify problem and to propose ways to improve them."
Study_location: Yangashan, Diebuzhai, Caoheba and Liziba CBCM Committees (villages of Shuigoubian, Qingyan- guan, Qingshuzhi, Majiaqiao and Wangjiaping were all under the lead of Liziba CBCM Committee) - Baishuijiang National Nature Reserve
Stated_outcomes: Ecological efficiency, Economic efficiency, social equity, institutional sustainability

Title: Forest incomes and poverty alleviation under participatory forest management in the Bale Highlands, Southern Ethiopia
Author_affil: Department of Forest Products, Swedish university of Agricultural sciences, P.O.Box 7060, SE-750-07, Vallv_gen 9A, Uppsala, Sweden
Funding: The scholarship that financed this research is funded by the Swedish International Development Agency.
Stated_int: Participatory forest management in Ethiopia: The participatory forest management (PFM) project in the Dodola forest was started as a pilot project with the major goal of organizing the local community in to a Forest Dwellers Association (WAJIB).
Desired_out: Improved livelihoods
Study_goal: This study aims at evaluating and explaining the contribution of forest resources to the livelihoods of local households in the context of participatory forest management arrangement in Ethiopia. It employs the sustainable livelihoods framework. The following are the main questions addressed in the study: ´ What is the contribution of forests to the rural livelihood in the study area and what are the most important forest products? ´ Are there patterns and seasonal variation in forest use, forest dependence, and forest product preference among income groups? ´ Are socio-economic characteristics of households important in explaining such patterns?
Study_location: Dodola woreda (district) which is located in the Bale zone of the Oromia regional state.
Stated_outcomes: Forest income by household income classes, Gini coefficient
Portion_livelihood_amount: forest products constitute an important part of the household income portfolio contributing 34% of total per capita income

Author_affil: Institute of Applied Ecology, Chinese Academy of Sciences
Funding: National Key Technologies R&D Program of China (2006BAD03A09), National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC40873067&30871958), and the 863 Program (2006AA10Z251)

Desired_out: "Ecotourism is thought to be an inevitable way for Chinese nature reserves to achieve sustainable development"
Study_goal: "The specific objectives of our study included: (1) to learn if local people had benefited from ecotourism; (2) to examine the extent to which ecotourism had influenced local attitudes; (3) to discuss factors that can influence local attitudes; and (4) to inform and improve nature reserve management in light of ecotourism development and associated impacts."
Study_location: Erdao Township, Changbai Mountain Biosphere Reserve (CMBR), located in Jilin Province of northeastern China [41Á41Í49î_42Á25Í18îN, 127Á42Í55î_128Á 16Í48îE]

Title: Social and environmental effects of ecotourism in the Osa Peninsula of Costa Rica: the Lapa Rios case
Author_affil: Department of Anthropology, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA; Carnegie Institution for Science, Department of Global Ecology, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA; Center for Responsible Travel, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA
Funding: Center for Latin American Studies at Stanford University
Stated_int: Certification for Sustainable Tourism, Lapa Rios Eco-lodge
Desired_out: Sustainable eco-tourism for ecological and human well-being benefits
Study_goal: "Our specific research questions are: 1) What have been the main social, economic, and environmental impacts _ positive and negative _ of ecotourism at Lapa Rios (LR)? (2) Have conservation efforts at the lodge been of sufficient magnitude and duration to alter deforestation trends in the property and surrounding areas as compared with the Osa Peninsula in general? (3) Has LR had an identifiable impact on local environmental awareness, and specifically, has it contributed to the spread of a conservation ethic among local residents?"
Study_location: Lapa-Rios Eco-lodge, Puerto Jimenez, Canaza, Palo Seco, La Palma - Osa Peninsula
Stated_outcomes: Household expenditure, income stability, knowledge, perception of impact

Title: Integrative Management of Commercialized Wild Mushroom: A Case Study of Thelephora ganbajun in Yunnan, Southwest China
Author_affil: Center for Mountain Ecosystem Studies, Kunming Institute of Botany, Kunming 650204, China
Funding: MISEREOR grant (335-031-1015Z) ‘‘Facilitating Community Driven Sustainable Development’’ and a Ford Foundation grant (1085-0573) for ‘‘Supporting the Upland Livelihoods in Southwest China: a Pilot Project for Sustainable Management of Non-Timber Forest Products’’
Stated_int: Integrative management of mushrooms (NTFPs)
Desired_out: Improve production and sustainability of Thelephora ganbajun. Interdisciplinary application to development of scientific basis for policy and management practice. Integrated biodiversity conservation with livelihood development.
Study_goal: This paper presents a pilot project of integrative management for improving the production and sustainable harvest of Thelephora ganbajun, an endemic and one of the most economically valuable mushroom species in South-west China. It aims to document an empirical case of how an interdisciplinary approach facilitated the development of scientific basis for policy and management practice, and built the local capacity to create, adopt and sustain the new rules and techniques of mushrooms management.' 'Using the results gained from the empirical case study, the paper suggest that the success of the interdisciplinary approach is significant in the context of policy decentralization and reform for integrating indigenous knowledge and extensive local participation in forest management and biodiversity conservation.'
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with natural vegetation
Stated_outcomes: Cash income from sale of mushrooms, opinions on best/effective regulation of harvest, change in production output between harvesting approaches

Title: Economic analysis of industrial agroforestry: poplar (Populus deltoides) in Uttar Pradesh (India)
Author_affil: Centre for Management in Agriculture, Indian Institute of Management, Vastrapur, Ahmedabad 380 015, India
Stated_int: Poplar-based agroforestry
Desired_out: Encouraged by Wimco (manufacturer of matches) - farmers grew poplar with technical and financial assistance, materials, and purchase guarantees from Wimco and National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development
Study_goal: This study examines the socio-economic profile of the poplar growers, costs and returns and employment potential of poplar-based agroforestry, and compares the economics of poplar-based agroforestry with traditional agri- culture. The objectives of this research are to determine the viability of poplar- based agroforestry alternatives and the impact of industry cost-sharing on the adoption of agroforestry. Finally, we examine farmers’ assessments of the effect of poplar on the quality of land and ground water.'
Study_location: Shahjahanpur district, Uttar Pradesh
Stated_outcomes: Costs and returns of agroforestry with and without Wimco assistance, and between agroforestry and traditional agriculture

Title: Application of a tri-capital community resilience framework for assessing the social–ecological system sustainability of community-based forest management in the Philippines
Author_affil: Graduate Program in Sustainability Science-Global Leadership Initiative, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, University of Tokyo, Rm#: 517, Building of Environmental Studies, 5-1-5, Kashiwanoha, Kashiwa, Chiba 277-8563, Japan
Funding: Japan’s Ministry of Education Culture, Sports, Science and Technology, the University of Tokyo’s Graduate Program in Sustainability Science-Global Leadership
Stated_int: the CBFM Agreement (CBFMA), with community organization-contractors, providing secure land tenure for a 25-year period and creating community subgroups entitled to distribute the land to individual members
Desired_out: National strategy to promote sustainable development of country's forestland resources and social equity
Study_goal: The research challenge is to develop and test applicability of a theoretical framework for measuring the inter- linked concepts of community resilience and SES resilience. Stated_int: N'hambita Community Carbon Project, Payments for Ecosystem Services, Plan Vivo system, carbon sequestration, ban on tree felling, fire patrols, promotion of microenterprises (sawmill, carpentry, etc...)

Title: Forest Management Policy and Community Well-Being in the Pacific Northwest
Author_affil: US Forest Service, Pacific Northwest Research Station
Stated_int: Northwest Forest Plan: Intensive timber management on federal lands came to an end in the early 1990s because of litigation over species protection under the Endangered Species and National Forest Management Acts (Thomas et al. 2006). The Northwest Forest Plan was adopted in 1994.
Desired_out: The Northwest Forest Plan aimed to provide “a sustainable level of human use of the forest resource while still meeting the need to maintain and restore the late-successional and old-growth forest ecosystem”
Study_goal: To study the effects of the Plan on communities, the socioeconomic monitoring team, which included the authors, examined links between Plan implementation, trends in goods, services, and opportunities from federal forests, and socioeconomic change in communities.
Study_location: Northwest USA
Stated_outcomes: Direct effects: jobs and contracting opportunities; Indirect effects: community socioeconomic conditions

Title: The public finance potential of community forestry in Nepal
Author_affil: Tribhuvan University, Institute of Forestry, Pokhara Campus, P.O. Box 43, Pokhara, Nepal
Funding: Consultative Research Committee (FFU) at the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs (grant no. 104.Dan.8.L.716) and The Danish Council for Independent Research —Social Sciences (j.no. 09-063842)
Stated_int: Community based forestry, specifically, redistribution of forest-generated income through taxation
Desired_out: To determine the public finance potential of community forestry in Nepal, or how redistribution through taxation of local forest use can result in pro-poor investments at the community level.
Int_dur: Community forestry has been in Nepal since the early 1990s
Study_goal: the study provides new empirical insights into the financial potential of community forestry
Study_location: The study was carried out in Gorkha District that forms part of the mid-Hills of the Western Region. The mid-Hill region of Nepal is centrally located, extending from the southern slope of the main Himalayan range to Mahabharat range, mostly between 700 and 4000 m altitude, and accounts for about 42% of total land area of the country

outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: During the first local auction in 2009, collectors received a price of IRs 21.15/kg1 as against the prices of IRs 10/kg in 2002–2003 when the leaves were last harvested from the study sites. In 2010, collectors received IRs 39/kg during the local auction. The gross margins of producers increased from 10% before intervention to 57% after the end of the second auction, thereby capturing a greater value share from the chain. The average income from bay leaves of the sampled households increased to an average of IRs 4700 after intervention in 2010 from IRs 1556 before intervention in 2003.

Title: Upgrading mountain people in medicinal and aromatic plants value chains: lessons for sustainable management and income generation from Uttarakhand, India
Journal: International Journal of Sustainable Development & World Ecology
Author_affil: Marketing and Enterprise Development Specialist, International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD), GPO Box 3226, Khumaltar, Kathmandu, Nepal
Funding: Overseas Development Institute (ODI), UK
Stated_int: Upgrading VC governance for NTFPs: This paper presents the findings of the action research on implementing upgrading strategies and actions with key stakeholders in the Cinnamomum tamala (Indian bay leaf) VC in Chamoli district of Uttrakhand, India. Policy readjustments through three independent but interlinked value chain (VC) upgrading strategies comprising of VC coordination upgrading, horizontal coordination and streamlined marketing were implemented together with stakeholders.
Desired_out: The address the constraints of collectors, who were vulnerable to state regulations that constrained their access to bay leaves in reserve forests and to MAPs markets that were established (in 2003) by the Government in the lowlands.
Study_goal: In the light of the challenges posed by NTFP VC governance, threats from unsustainable management and low returns to collectors, it aims to enhance understanding of how VC upgrading strategies that are sensitive to the mountain specificities affect the terms of participation of mountain people and their impacts on resource management and local income generation.
Study_location: Chamoli district lies in the north-eastern part of Uttarakhand State in the Western Indian Himalayas
Stated_outcomes: Income from bay leaves

Title: Community attitudes toward forest conservation programs through collaborative protected area management in Bangladesh
Author_affil: Department of Forest Science, Faculty of Agriculture, Shinshu University, 8304 Minamiminowa-Mura, Nagano-Ken 399-4598, Japan
Stated_int: Forest co-management program: augmented skills by trainings on alternative income generating (AIG) activities and getting agricultural lands leased from the Forest Department
Desired_out: Increased income; improve attitudes among local people to conservation initiatives
Int_dur: Since 2004: In order to reduce pressure on the sanctuary, the Forest Department has introduced several alternative income generation (AIG) activities for local communities while initiating the co-management approach under the Nishorgo Support Project (NSP) in 2004.
Study_goal: This paper analyzes the attitudes toward conservation by members of local communities living in and around the wildlife sanctuary. Training incentives on alternative income-generating (AIG) activities and allotment of agricultural lands were distributed among the Forest User Groups. It is of interest to policy makers and resource managers whether this technique leads to improved attitudes on the part of local people.
Study_location: Rema-Kalenga Wildlife Sanctuary (Fig. 1) is situated in Gazipur and Ranigaon unions (small administrative unit of the local government) of Chunarughat upazila (sub-district) in Habigonj district, Bangladesh (24060–24140N latitude and 91340–91410E longitude)
Study_duration: This was a micro-approach study, conducted among the members of the FUGs of Rema- Kalenga Wildlife Sanctuary in the months of January and February 2009
Stated_outcomes: Change in average annual household income before/after joining the FUG; changing patterns of community attitudes towards conservation

outcome.Indicators: Forest investments: frequency of investment activities including planting seeds, trees, and bushes
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: This analysis suggests that after decentralization the proportion of user groups making forest improvements in Bolivia was not significantly affected. In Uganda, decentralization years saw a slight increase in the proportion of forest improvements by 0.12 (p < 0.05), and in Mexico the probability of forest investments during decentralization increased by 0.25 (p < 0.10). In Kenya, decentralization years are associated with a much lower proportion of user groups making forest investments; the proportion fell by 0.26 (p < 0.05).

outcome.Indicators: Rulemaking - The variable for rulemaking is a binary variable indicating if the user group makes rules (=1) or not (=0).

outcome.Indicators: Wealth inequality.
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: The nearly exact matching results report that in Bolivia and Mexico the years of decentralization are associated with a decrease in the proportion of user groups with an uneven wealth distribution. In Bolivia, this decrease is slight and statistically insignificant, while in Mexico, the years of decentralization are associated with a decreased proportion of over 0.3 (p < 0.10). In the African countries we find that wealth inequalities are exacerbated by decentralization. While wealth distribution did not change very much in Kenya (and was not statistically significant), the proportion of user groups with an unequal wealth distribution in Uganda significantly increased by 0.26 (p < 0.01).

Title: Comparing Forest Decentralization and Local Institutional Change in Bolivia, Kenya, Mexico, and Uganda
Author_affil: Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL, USA
Funding: Sustainable Agriculture and Natural Resource Management Collaborative Research Support Program (SANREM), the Workshop in Political Theory and Policy Analysis, and the International Forestry Resources and Institutions Program. Additional funding for Forrest Fleischman’s work on this project came from a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship #2007054263
Linked_refs: Yes same dataset as Coleman and Mwangi 2013
Stated_int: Forest decentralization in Bolivia, Kenya, Mexico, and Uganda
Desired_out: Community empowerment, sustainable forest use
Int_dur: Varies by country studied. Bolivia: 1997; Kenya: 2005; Mexico: 2003; Uganda: 2003
Study_goal: In this paper we use these frameworks to develop a theory of how changes in accountability and user empowerment that result from decentralization policies impact user group behavior and forest conditions. We then test this theory using a unique over-time dataset on forest resources and institutions in Bolivia, Kenya, Mexico, and Uganda, which allows us to test theories across a broader range of cases than has been possible in previous work.
Study_location: Data are taken from the International Forestry Resources and Institutions (IFRI) research program for each country.
Stated_outcomes: Decentralization effects on forest investments; rulemaking, wealth inequality, and forest conditions

Title: Performance of an agro-forestry based Payments-for-Environmental-Services project in Mozambique: A household level analysis
Author_affil: Horticulture Australia Limited, Australia
Funding: Hampton Grant from the University of British Columbia, World Bank-administered Trust Fund for Environmentally and Socially Sustainable Development through Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR), and International Development Research Centre (IDRC) through a Doctoral Research Fellowship.
Stated_int: N'hambita Payments for Ecosystems Services project. Small-scale agroforestry based carbon sequestration project. Carbon Livelihoods Project. Plan Vivo System
Desired_out: Voluntary contracts with smallholder farmers to plant trees on farms (commercial fruit, local fruit, indigenous timber) and manage for 25 years in return for conditional cash payments. Participatory format. Community development initiatives including livestock, bees, and cultivation.
Study_goal: To address some of the deficiencies in previous studies, we conducted a household level study in a PES-project area in Mozambique. Using data collected from household surveys, this paper will address the following questions: (1) Do people benefit from participating in a PES project? (2) Are there any biases in the distribution of the PES project benefits among the participants? Answer to these questions helps to improve the assessment of the economic impacts and effectiveness of PES projects at the household level; to more carefully analyse the social equity issues for the poorest and the most vulnerable households; and to provide some useful insights for designing future PES projects. The remainder of this paper introduces the study site, describes the experimental design, identifies the key results and dis- cusses the main outcomes and conclusions.'
Study_location: Chicale Regulado in buffer zone of Gorongosa National Park in Sofala Province. N'hambita, Bue Maria, Munhanganha, Pungue, and Mbulawa villages
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with planted trees, trees on farms, or tree farms
Stated_outcomes: Consumption expenditure, cash income from trees

Title: Equity in Distribution of Proceeds from Forest Products from Certified Community-Based Forest Management in Kilwa District, Tanzania
Author_affil: Department of Ecology and Natural Resource Management, Norwegian University of Life Sciences (NMBU), Post Box 5003, 1432 As, Norway
Funding: Climate Change Impacts, Adaptation and Mitigation (CCIAM) Program in Tanzania
Stated_int: Forest Stewardship Council certified forests, community forestry
Desired_out: One of the objectives of certified community forestry initiatives is meeting ethical and social commitments regarding equity in benefits distribution among various actors along the chain'
Study_goal: Despite FSC’s goal of enhancing equitable distribution of benefits, its ability to do so, especially to owners and producers of forests and forest products, has been questioned (see Duchelle et al. 2014). Yet equity aspects of benefits from certified community forests have not been fully examined quantitatively for the various actors (e.g. see Beauchamp and Ingram 2011; Pinto and McDermott 2013). To bridge this knowledge gap, the study carries out a comparative analysis to assess certified village forests (FSC) and non-certified village (non-FSC) forests products income and distribution among various actors in Kilwa District, Tanzania. By using a value chain analysis (VCA) framework, a closer investigation is conducted into the distribution of proceeds from forest products through assessing: a) types of costs and benefits of forest products to various actors; b) distribution of benefits among the actors and c) forest resource use governance.'
Study_location: Kikole, Kisangi, Mchakama, and Likawage villages, Kilwa district (8°15'–10°00'S and 38°40'–39°40'E) in Lindi
Stated_outcomes: Net revenues earned, value chain governance (access to resources, bylaw compliance)

Title: Effects of a policy-induced income shock on forest-dependent households in the Peruvian Amazon
Author_affil: Department of Geography, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 550 North Park Street, Madison, WI 53706-1404 USA
Funding: This research was supported by the Fulbright Foundation, the Conference of Latin Americanist Geographers, the Nave Foundation, and the NSF-IGERT Program
Stated_int: Managed Forest Law (Act No. 27308), block harvesting
Desired_out: Timber sector reforms to move towards sustainable logging and compliance with US timber export market. Change in local logging practices in remote communities from traditional family timber camps to annual block harvesting
Study_goal: We examine outcomes of a recent logging reform in Peru with a case study concerning strongly forest-dependent communities in a biodiverse and carbon-heavy region. We first describe how the logging reform resulted in lost access despite intensive efforts by third-parties to facilitate local logging in compliance with the new rules. Next, we test whether households adapted to the income shock by shifting to other activities to compensate for lost logging income.... Third, we identify characteristics of households that proved to be better able to adapt to logging losses by earning large incomes from NTFPs after the rule change.'
Study_location: Loreto region
Stated_outcomes: Change in income composition and total

Title: Logging Concessions and Local Livelihoods in Cameroon: from Indifference to Alliance?
Author_affil: CIRAD, CIFOR
Funding: This work was carried out for the project “Popular” with the financial support of the French National Research Agency under the Agriculture and Sustainable Development Programme
Stated_int: Logging concessions as forest management model
Desired_out: Logging concessions are agreements primarily between logging company and government on rights and ability to harvest timber, however, it covers communal and village forest areas as well.  Thus forest management plans include village committees to involve local people at various stages of the management process. Additionally, as part concession, logging companies have to participate in improving living conditions of local population both through payments and social works
Study_goal: To examine the connection between the application of the concession model and the variation of local livelihoods, the article focuses on the Cameroon situation, the most advanced country in enforcing forest management in the Congo Basin region (de Wasseige et al. 2009), and considers two levels of analysis. After presenting the methods and context of study, we assess the overall impact at the national scale of direct contributions from logging concessions to their surrounding villages. We then consider how local livelihoods in two communities have evolved during the last decade in the vicinity of a logging concession. We conclude on the potentiality of the forest concession model to indirectly favor local livelihoods.'
Study_location: Goute and Djemiong villages
Stated_outcomes: Change in physical capital, natural capital and financial capital

Title: Have We Managed to Integrate Conservation and Development? ICDP Impacts in the Brazilian Amazon
Author_affil: Inter-American Development Bank, Brasilia, Brazil
Funding: USDA Forest Service International Programs Office and the Amazon Institute for People and the Environment (IMAZON)
Linked_refs: Weber et al. 2011, Pattanayak and Sills 2001
Stated_int: Protected areas with Integrated Conservation and Development Projects (ICDPs), Community-based enterprise (CBE), Tapajos National Forest, ProManejo, Pilot Program for Tropical Forest Protection (PPG7)
Desired_out: The Amazon Sustainable Forest Management Support Project (ProManejo) was a component of the Pilot Program for Tropical Forest Protection (PPG7), financed by the World Bank, DFID, GTZ, the Brazilian government and the German development bank, KfW. The objective was to finance pilot programs and demonstration projects to support the development and adoption of sustainable forest management systems in the Amazon (Dias, 2001), including an entire component on management of the Tapajos National Forest as a demonstration project for Sustainable Use Protected Areas....The Tapajos National Forest component aimed to demonstrate sustainable forest management with community involvement, with the complementary goal of improving livelihoods in the traditional riverine communities of the Tapajos (ibama, 2009). This included support for CBEs to process and market non-timber forest products and services: eco-tourism, natural oils, wood artisan products, and “ecological leather” made from natural rubber. ...The CBEs were intended to encourage community-based forest management, to increase and diversify household income, and to improve relations between the communities and the National Forest, contributing to the long-term conservation of the forest.'
Study_goal: We evaluate an enterprise-based conservation strategy in a high-profile and well-funded ICDP in the Tapajos National Forest of Brazil.' Specifically estimating the causal impact on livelihood outcomes for participatants in the CBEs.
Study_location: Tapajos National Forest
Stated_outcomes: Cash income, assets, heads of cattle, agricultural area used, # of forest collection trips, # NTFPs collected and sold

Title: Evaluating China’s Slope Land Conversion Program as sustainable management in Tianquan and Wuqi Counties
Author_affil: Department of Geography and the Environment, The University of Texas at Austin, United States
Funding: National Science Foundation as part of a project entitled An Integrative Impact Evaluation of China’s Ecological Restoration Programs. Additional research funding was provided by the Rapoport-King thesis scholarship through the College of Liberal Arts at The University of Texas at Austin.
Stated_int: Sloping Land Conversion Program (SLCP), Grain for Green Program, afforestation
Desired_out: The mission of the SLCP, also known as the “Grain for Green” program, is to reduce soil erosion from sloped, degraded cropland by converting these areas to forest or grassland cover. Farmers in the Yellow and Yangtze River basins and other erosion-prone areas are expected to convert their sloped agricultural land in exchange for a financial subsidy.'
Study_goal: Given the scale of the program, it is clear that detailed empirical studies are needed to understand its social and ecological effects. This paper works to address this need by analyzing the effects of the SLCP within rural economies and household livelihood systems. We concentrate in particular upon labor distribution and income sources to examine how farmers have adjusted to the program’s restrictions. A comparative case study between Tianquan County, Sichuan Province and Wuqi County, Shaanxi Province is used to analyze how rural areas with different economic patterns have responded to the program.'
Study_location: 6 villages in Tianquan County-Jishijuan + Xinditou villages (Zishi Township), Sijing + Madu villages (Sijing Township), Xikou + Yanfeng villages (Renyi Township); 16 villages in Wuqi County (Wuqi, Xinzhai, Wu Cang Bao, Wu Gu Cang, Guanmiao, Qwan Zi Townships)
Stated_outcomes: Environmental change, change in primary income source (recall), off-farm opportunities (recall)

Title: Women’s participation in forest management: A cross-country analysis
Author_affil: Department of Political Science, Florida State University, 543 Bellamy, Tallahassee, FL 32306-2230, USA
Funding: Sustainable Agriculture and Natural Resource Management Collaborative Research Support Program (SANREM), National Science Foundation (SES0648447) for data collection, the Austrian Development Agency for data analysis and reporting, the Workshop in Political Theory and Policy Analysis, and the International Forestry Resources and Institutions Program.
Linked_refs: Yes this study uses the same dataset as Coleman and Fleischman 2012
Stated_int: Womens' participation in forest user groups
Desired_out: Women's empowerment
Int_dur: Varies by country; paper doesn't specify
Study_goal: In this paper we advance the research on gender, participation, and forestry in a number of important ways. First, we assess participation in terms of a more complete probability model using the theoretical insights of Agarwal (2001) by collecting data on all of the factors she argues are associated with women’s participation. Thus, we are able to test competing hypotheses meant to explain participation that more fully capture the relevant theoretical expectations. Second, while most of the previous literature surveys communities as the unit of analysis, we use household level survey data to compare the responsibility of women and men within the household. Specifically, we examine whether responsibilities for participation fall mostly upon the wife, husband, are equally shared, or whether there is no participation by the household at all. Third, we then extend this analysis to examine what effects the different configurations of participation have on institutional outcomes from the forest user groups (FUGs). Fourth, our data analysis uses data from a household survey administered in Bolivia, Kenya, Mexico, and Uganda and thus provides an extension of the previous literature to these countries. Fifth, and finally, we also examine the results from an analysis of formal forest user associations in 10 countries in order to assess broader measures of participation (including women’s participation with forest association councils and their leadership positions).
Study_location: Varies by country - data taken for Bolivia, Kenya, Mexico and Uganda from 2 sources: IFRI Program: 23 sites in four countries (Bolivia, Kenya, Mexico, and Uganda) identified by the International Forestry Resources and Institutions (IFRI) program in 2008; and more aggregated dataset taken from 96 forest associations in 10 countries of the IFRI program.
Study_duration: Household surveys conducted in 2008; date not indicated for IFRI aggregate data
Stated_outcomes: Determinants of women's participation (IFRI household data); women's participation (IFRI aggregate data) - total number of councilors that are women, the probability that the leader of the forest association is a woman
