outcome.Indicators: Effect of household’s dependence on forests on participation in JFM
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: Stepwise logit regression results are portrayed in Table 9. In the primary regression model (step-I) physical dependence on forest (man-days employment in NTFPs and persons involved in forestry) is merely the main policy variable (explanatory variable) affecting households’ participation in forestry. Afterwards we gradually increase the number of explanatory variables one by one in separate regression models, say monetary dependence on forest (share of income from forest sector) in step-II, literacy level in step-III and so on. Finally, in step-VII we include all possible explanatory variables. As the table shows, all the explanatory variables are of expected sign (positive) and almost all of them are observed to be significant factors influencing participation.

Stated_int: Forest Act, forest user groups (FUG)
Desired_out: the Forest Act of 1993 that transferred all accessible forestland from the central government to local communities through the creation of ‘‘Forest User Groups’'. ... The Forest Act redirects the field staff (‘‘foresters’’) of the Department of Forests from protecting national forests towards building forest user groups to manage all of the nation’s forestland without interference from outside of the community. Title: Extracting Value from the Forest: Lessons learned in the Acre landscape, Brazil
Author_affil: IUCN
Stated_int: IUCN Livelihoods and Landscapes Strategy Program
Desired_out: IUCN’s LLS project, which was initiated in 2007, sought to assist the forest-dwelling communities to create value from the extraction of non-timber forest products, specifically from wood, rubber, and Brazil nuts to enhance their livelihoods. It was also intended to demonstrate that values from extractive products could be a viable alternative to activities such as cattle ranching and farming. Working with two local cooperatives, COOPERACRE and COOPERFLORESTA, to ensure optimum stakeholder engagement, the LLS project sought to: - Support the development of community and local cooperatives that support the commercialization of timber and non-timber forest products, through enhanced communication, improved access to markets and better administration, and through the application of best practices (including different certification schemes). - Improve participation of civil society in decision-making fora such as: i) Tripartite State Councils for forests, environment, science and technology and household production, and ii) multi-stakeholder dialogues for value chains (Brazil nut, rubber and timber). - Support landscape restoration through the programme to Increase Value of Forest Activities (Programa de Valorización de los Activos Forestales), an innovation of the state government of Acre.'
Study_goal: This paper focuses on efforts to create value from non-timber forest products in the Acre region in the north-western part of the Amazon region in Brazil.'
Study_location: Acre
Stated_outcomes: Changes in household incomes from forest products supported by program (brazil nuts, timber, rubber)

Title: Equity Mechanisms in Traditional Forest Management Systems: A Case Study of Loita Forest in Kenya
Author_affil: Kenya Forestry Research Institute, Nairobi, Kenya
Funding: Financial support was provided by the Kenya Forest Research Institute and the European Union through Care International offices in Kenya and Uganda.
Stated_int: Traditional Community Based Forest Management, Participatory Forest Management, Forest Act of 2005
Desired_out: The aim of TCBFM as a form of community-based forestry is to empower those who work, live, and recreate in the woods to recognize and strive for a common set of goals'
Study_goal: The objective of the study is to document the equity mechanisms in the traditional management of the Loita forest in Kenya.... 1. Can TCBFM contribute to poverty reduction by providing rural people with a sustainable and equitably distributed stream of net benefits? 2. If yes, how significant are the benefits (in relation to other income- generating activities and sources of livelihood) for the well-being of the different groups? If no, what are the key negative impacts of TCBFM—and on whom do they fall—and are there ways of minimizing, mitigating, or reversing these? 3. What changes in policy, institutions, and legal frameworks have the potential to enhance the contributions of TCBFM to poverty alleviation?'
Study_location: The Naimina-Enkiyio forest (Loita forest) 1◦ 36′ S and within longitudes 35.8◦ and 36.1◦ E
Stated_outcomes: Economic capital, social capital, physical capital, political capital, natural capital
Stated_mech: Equity

Title: Building on traditional gardening to improve household food security
Author_affil: Rural Institutions and Participation Service of FAO’s Sustainable Development Department
Stated_int: Home gardens, Helen Keller International (HKI) project, nutrition education
Desired_out: As part of its global effort to eliminate vitamin A deficiency and nutritional blindness, the NGO Helen Keller International (HKI) implemented a home gardening and nutrition education project in Bangladesh (Marsh and Talukder, 1994; Marsh, 1998; Talukder and Bloem, 1993; HKI/AVRDC, 1993). Between 1990 and 1993, a pilot project in Panchagaor District, northwestern Bangladesh, tested whether promotion of low-cost vegetable gardens combined with nutrition education might be a viable strategy for improving the nutritional levels of near-landless, at-risk populations, particularly women and young children...Community involvement is crucial for sustainability of home gardening activities, and the project developed a two- way information flow to disseminate knowledge among extension workers, group leaders and women gardeners and their families.'

Title: Measuring effectiveness, efficiency and equity in an experimental Payments for Ecosystem Services trial
Author_affil: University of East Anglia, School of International Development, Norwich NR4 7TJ, United Kingdom
Funding: European Research Council (Grant No. GA 206994 REDIRECT)
Stated_int: Payments for Ecosystem Services, (REDIRECT), Nyungwe National Park
Desired_out: In our own PES trial, (a) communities enter into contracts voluntarily, (b) we (a research partnership backed by EU funding) pay communities to provide specified conservation services, and (c) payments are conditional based on measured performance of those services. ... We provided financial incentives to communities to reduce activities that were widely considered to be detrimental to biodiversity conservation, predominantly hunting with snares, cutting trees, and mining. At the same time, we incentivized those activities outside of the park that were considered to support reduction of these in-park activities in the long-term, mainly private tree and bamboo planting.'
Study_goal: The research presented here contributes to this work by using an experimental design to evaluate Payments for Ecosystem Services as a tool for supporting biodiversity conservation in the context of an African protected area'
Study_location: Nyungwe National Park (adjacent)
Stated_outcomes: Change in consumption, elite capture of benefits, equity of social impacts, behavioral change

Title: Measuring the forest and income impacts of forest user group participation under Malawi's Forest Co-management Program
Author_affil: International Food Policy Research Institute, Lilongwe, Malawi
Funding: United States Agency for International Development Cooperative Agreement No. AID-OAA-L-12-00001 with the BASIS Feed the Future Innovation Lab
Stated_int: Forest Co-Management Program, decentralization of forest management
Desired_out: Acknowledging the key role of forests for national development, the GoM implemented a pilot FCM program in Chimaliro and Liwonde Forest Reserves in 1996 with the aid of the World Bank and the Department for International Development (DFID). The FCM involved distributing shared responsibility for forest management among primary stake- holders. In concept, co-management is a decentralized approach to decision making that includes consultation by and with all stakeholders, with duties and responsibilities outlined in a management plan (GoM, 2003). Stated goals in Malawi were to improve rural livelihoods, enhance household food security, and preserve forest resources (Mayers et al., 2001).'
Study_goal: In this paper we pursue two objectives. First, we examine whether household participation in the FCM through forest user groups (FUGs) has had any measurable association with decisions to clear forests for agricultural expansion. ...Subsequent to this first investigation, we examine whether the program has had any measurable effect, positive or negative, on household forest incomes, which we define as cash income arising from the sales of products from the co-managed forests combined with cash payments earned from FCM participation. '
Study_location: Kasungu (Chimaliro Forest Reserve) and Machinga (Liwonde Forest Reserve) Districts
Stated_outcomes: Effects of participation on household forest income, effect of participation on decision to clear forests

Title: Allocation of degraded hillsides to landless farmers and improved livelihoods in Tigray, Ethiopia
Journal: Norsk Geografisk Tidsskrift - Norwegian Journal of Geography
Author_affil: Department of Geography and Environmental Studies, Mekelle University, P.O. Box 231, Mekelle, Ethiopia; Department of Geography, Ghent University, Krijgslaan 281 S8, BE 9000 Gent, Belgium
Stated_int: Land improvement of degraded hillsides, hillside plantations, reforestation
Desired_out: Land rehabilitation is seen as the most viable way of miti- gating the effects of land degradation. Accordingly, a number of projects under the poverty reduction strategy ‘To plough from poverty to productivity’ that was implemented in 2005 by the Government of Ethiopia and aided by local non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and international NGOs (Haile et al. 2006), have been run as part of a long-standing struggle against soil erosion and drought in the northern highlands of Ethiopia. As a result, since the mid-1990s, forest cover has been improved by the establishment of exclosures (e.g. Asefa et al. 2003) and woodlots (Jagger & Pender 2003), as well as agroforestry, land certification for use, and integrated soil and water management (Haile et al. 2006). In addition, some land rehabilitation activities have been undertaken via food-for-work schemes.' 'In 1991, the idea of dividing the degraded and unproductive communal hillsides into smaller plots and allocating them to individuals for tree planting was initiated by local communities. Community elders and priest farmers described their ideas through the use of chronological depictions of interventions intended to provide solutions to degraded hillsides, and showed a timeline for the pro- posed activities. In this way, members of the local communities were able to express their wishes for the hills to become productive once again and hence transform their livelihoods. The demand-driven initiative was sub- sequently put into practice by local administrators and influenced both the regional land policy and the national land policy. '
Study_goal: The authors assessed the effect of hillside plantations on the livelihoods of landless farmers in the eastern part of the Tigray Region'
Study_location: Ahrag, Dongar, Adikeshi, Kalhabile villages in the Tigray Region
Stated_outcomes: Economic benefits, determinants of hillside management

Title: Social and Environmental Impacts of Forest Management Certification in Indonesia
Author_affil: The Nature Conservancy, Fort Collins, CO, United States of America
Funding: Duke University, WWF-US
Stated_int: Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) forest management certification
Desired_out: Initiated by non-governmental conservation organizations, the FSC program emerged in 1993 to promote the sustainable management of forests globally [9]. The general goals of the FSC program are to achieve “environmentally appropriate”, “socially beneficial”, and “economically viable” timber harvest- ing in logging concessions [17]. In addition to providing incentives to companies to incorporate the social costs of timber production, the FSC certification criteria emphasize compliance with law and international agreements; tenure security and conflict resolution among stakeholders; recognition of indigenous people’s land rights; community relations and workers’ rights; investments to maintain biodiversity; the ecological productivity of the area; minimized waste and damage to other resources like soil and water due to road construction; enhanced forest regeneration, monitoring and assessments of impacts of activities; and maintenance of high conservation value forests [17] (Fig 1).'
Study_goal: Using temporally and spatially explicit village-level data on environmental and socio-economic indicators in Kalimantan (Indonesia), we evaluate the performance of the FSC-certified timber concessions compared to non-certified logging concessions.'
Study_location: Kalimantan
Stated_outcomes: Changes to environment, changes to household welfare, changes in village development

Title: Unpacking the impacts of ‘participatory’ forestry policies: Evidence from Kenya
Author_affil: Wangari Maathai Institute for Peace and Environmental Studies, 30197-00100, University of Nairobi, Kenya
Funding: The research was undertaken under the project ‘Stabilizing Kenya by Solving Forest Related Conflicts’ (STAKE) financed by the Consultative Research Committee for Development Research under the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Danida), grant 11-036KU.
Stated_int: Participatory forest management, community forest associations (CFA)
Desired_out: PFM was introduced in Kenya following pressure mostly from civil society organizations as an approach to ensure sustainable forest management '
Study_goal: This study illustrates an impact evaluation of the livelihoods outcomes of PFM in Kenya. It does so by comparing members and non- members of community forestry associations (CFA) among communities living adjacent to the Eburu and Sururu Forest Reserves. Specifically, we examine the policy of PFM as it unfolds in practice on the ground and seek to evaluate its impacts through matching of CFA and non-CFA member (NCFA) households based on re-call data to generate estimates of impacts on household income.
Study_location: Sururu and Eburu forest of Eastern Mau Forest Reserve
Stated_outcomes: Average impact of PFM on rurallivelihoods

Title: Access to benefits from forest commons in the Western Himalayas
Author_affil: Department of Economics, Wright State University, 3640 Colonel Glenn Highway, Dayton, OH, 45435 USA
Funding: The Department of Resource Economics, University of Massachusetts Amherst
Stated_int: Community forestry, devolution of rights, joint forest management (JFM)
Desired_out: Himachal Pradesh first initiated forest co-management in a limited area under a JFM scheme9 in 1993 with funding from Department for International Development, a UK-based development agency. Thereafter, additional state-funded community forestry schemes were announced extending the scope of co-management to a wider area within Himachal Pradesh (Vasan, 2003). Under the tenets of co-management, rights and responsibilities concerning forests are vested in the village community, and technical and financial assistance are provided by the state through the Forest Department (Vasan, 2003, 2006). In addition, the co- management schemes are integrated with development programs to promote the overall wellbeing of the communities (GoHP, 2001). To fulfill objectives of equity, membership is extended to all households in the village (specifically one male and one female member of the household). In Himachal Pradesh, an estimated 500 community-forest institutions were established under JFM by early 2000s'
Study_goal: A central objective of this paper is therefore to examine the effects of forest management regimes on access to forest benefits in forest communities in the Indian Himalayas. ...Utilizing the statistical method of generalized linear models (GLM), the paper tests whether forest access differs across state, co-management and traditional forest management regimes. A second objective is to investigate the effects of wealth on forest access and specifically to ascertain the impact of community forestry on forest access to the land-poor households.'
Study_location: Himachal Pradesh
Stated_outcomes: Differences in forest access

Title: Impact of agroforestry intervention on soil fertility and farm income under the subsistence farming system of the middle hills, Nepal
Author_affil: School of Environment, Resources and Development, Asian Institute of Technology, P.O. Box 4, Klong Luang, Pathumthani 12120, Thailand
Stated_int: Promotion of agroforestry
Desired_out: Aiming to increase fodder production, Nepal Agroforestry Foundation (NAF), a Kathmandu-based NGO, has been engaged in promoting agroforestry in five hill districts of Nepal, namely, Chitwan, Dhading, Kavrepalanchowk, Ramechhap and Sindhupalanchowk. The NAF, as an umbrella organization, works with 113 farmer groups through the network of 18 local NGOs and 10 forestry user groups (FUGs) in these districts. The project households have planted improved fodder and grass species as part of a NAF promoted agroforestry program. Promoted species include ipil ipil, calliandra, bhatmase (Flemingia con- gesta), mulberry (Morus alba), gauzuma (Gauzuma ulmiformis), NB 21 (Pennisetum sp.), napier (Pen- nisetum purpureum) and stylo (Stylosanthes guianen- sis).'
Study_goal: With a particular reference to the NAF-initiated project in Kumpur, Nalang and Salang village development committee (VDC) areas of Dhading district, the objectives to this study were: (1) to analyze the impact of an agroforestry intervention on soil fertility based on soil analysis and farmers’ perception; and (2) to compare the profitability of traditional and agroforestry-based farming systems using benefit–cost analysis. '
Study_location: Kumpur, Salang, and Nalang Village Development Committee Areas (Dhading District)
Stated_outcomes: Changes in soil fertility, profitability of agroforestry

Title: Impacts of Community-Based Natural Resource Management on Wealth, Food Security and Child Health in Tanzania
Author_affil: Clark University, Economics Department, Worcester, Massachusetts, United States of America
Stated_int: Community-based natural resource management (CBNRM), joint forest management (JFM), community-based forest management (CBFM), wildlife management areas (WMA)
Desired_out: In the late 1990's and early 2000's the Tanzanian government passed several pieces of legislation calling for devolution of natural resource governance to local populations through various CBNRM activities, CBFM, JFM and WMAs. Although community forest activities began as early as 1991, it was the 1998 Forest Policy and 2002 Forest Act that legally supported and facilitated community management and ownership of forests through JFM and CBFM [15,19]. Regulations for both CBFM and JFM were published in 2007; benefit-sharing arrangements were later published in 2014. The 1998 Wildlife Policy provided new opportunities for community management of wildlife resources [20]. WMA regulations were formulated in 2002 alongside the establishment of the first WMA, but a new Wildlife Policy in 2007 and ‘Non-Consumptive Utilization of Wildlife Regulations’ in 2008 recentralized many powers and benefits to the government [21]. Revised WMA regulations in 2012 promised to return more control and benefits to communities.'
Study_goal: Here, we use a difference-in-differences estimation strategy to determine the impact of three different CBNRM approaches, Joint Forest Management (JFM), Community-based Forest Management (CBFM) and Wildlife Management Areas (WMAs), on wealth, food security and health outcomes in Tanzania. Difference-in-differences models estimate the impact of treatment by calculating the difference in change over time between a treated group and a non- treated group before and after treatment ... As such, we can determine: 1) if CBNRM in Tanzania has had an impact on participating communities' well-being and 2) to what extent the effect of CBNRM varies depending upon the type of CBNRM governance regime.'
Study_location: Tanzania
Stated_outcomes: Change in wealth status, food security, and health outcomes compared between JFM, CBFM, WMA village households (treated) and non-CBNRM households (untreated) before and after implementation

Authors: Persha L, Andersson K

outcome.Indicators: Skewness in distribution of harvest benefits from forest products that are universally perceived to be most important across members of each user group
outcome.Outcome.direction_notes: Forest decentralization increases risk of elite capture of forest product benefits

Title: Elite capture risk and mitigation in decentralized forest governance regimes
Author_affil: Department of Geography, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Campus Box #3220, Chapel Hill, NC 27599-3220, United States
Funding: National Science Foundation (grants SES- 648447, DEB-1114984)
Stated_int: Forest sector decentralization
Desired_out: Over the past thirty years, nearly all developing countries in the world have passed legislation to decentralize at least some portion of the rights, responsibilities, and public resources associated with natural resource governance to local administrative bodies, local community groups (communal management), or some combination of these agents (co-management)'
Study_goal: Here we examine how forest sector decentralization affects local-level institutional arrangements and, in turn, the risk of elite capture, using a longitudinal social–ecological dataset from 56 forests and 174 community groups across four countries. Our aim is two-fold: (1) to test our dataset for empirical support of the conventional wisdom that elite capture increases under forest-sector decentralization; and (2) to test whether a key institutional design factor hypothesized in the literature (external accountability) indeed can play a significant role in reducing the likelihood of elite capture of forest resources under prevailing decentralization policies represented by the countries in our dataset.'
Study_location: India, Kenya, Nepal, Uganda
Stated_outcomes: Likelihood of elite capture of forest resources

Title: Good Governance Assessment in Nepal’s Community Forestry
Author_affil: Institute of Forestry, Tribhuvan University, Pokhara, Nepal
Funding: Community Based Natural Forest and Tree Management (CoMForM) project
Stated_int: Community forest user groups, explicit female inclusion, Livelihoods Forestry Program and the Biodiversity Sector Program for Siwalik and Tarai
Desired_out: Nepal’s Forestry Sector Master Plan was the landmark policy document recognizing women as primary users of forest resources. It made a policy recommendation for participation of at least one-third women in the executive committees of CFUGs (Ministry of Forests and Soil Conservation [MFSC], 1988). Similarly, new policy guidelines of Nepal’s community forestry man- dated that one-half of CFUGs executive committee members be women, and that either the secretary or chairperson posts be reserved for women as well (MFSC, 2009). The executive committee is one forum where forest management decisions are made. These guidelines also encourage CFUGs to form an inclusive committee by representing socially excluded groups such as poor and dalit households. The formation of an inclusive committee is considered to be an important step in the process of ensuring that forest users feel good about the governance of community forestry'
Study_goal: This study aims to examine forest governance by assessing whether the executive committees of Nepal’s Community Forest User Groups (CFUGs) are inclusive in terms of gender, caste, and wealth class'
Study_location: Myadgi, Makwanpur, Dhading, Tanahu, Kaski districts
Stated_outcomes: Inclusion in CFUG leadership compared between gender, poor and non-poor, dalit and non-dalit, as well as between CFUGs with and without project support

Title: Socio-economic Comparison Between Traditional and Improved Cultivation Methods in Agroforestry Systems, East Usambara Mountains, Tanzania
Author_affil: Viikki Tropical Recourses Institute (VITRI), University of Helsinki, 00014 Finland
Stated_int: Improved agroforestry
Desired_out: In farms with improved agroforestry systems, the land use is well planned and land is effectively used; multipurpose trees, many of them nitrogen-fixing species, are planted as windbreak, shelterbelts, or around the fields. Trees are also intercropped with annual crops or alley farming is practiced between the crop lines to reduce soil erosion. Well-managed cash crops are grown with a good diversity of annual and perennial crops. If the farm has cattle, the manure is used for crops. Farmers have obtained information about soil and water conservation and improved agroforestry techniques from extension services and study tours through different development projects in the area.'
Study_goal: This study reports the findings of a socio-economic comparison between traditional cultivation methods and improved agroforestry systems in the East Usambara.'
Study_location: Shebomeza,Mlesa, Meshewa, Kimbo zones in buffer zone of Amani Nature Reserve
Stated_outcomes: Cash crop revenues, productivity, livestock owned

Title: IMPACTS OF PARTICIPATORY TREE DOMESTICATION ON FARMER LIVELIHOODS IN WEST AND CENTRAL AFRICA
Author_affil: ICRAF West and Central Africa Region, P 0 Box 16 317 Yaounde Cameroon
Funding: International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), the Belgian Development Cooperation (DGDC) and the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)
Stated_int: Participatory indigenous tree domestication, training
Desired_out: the World Agroforestry Centre (ICRAF) in West and Central Africa started research on participatory tree domestication in 1996 with the objective of increasing incomes of rural communities and enhancing the resilience of their livelihoods by cultivating indigenous trees and developing strategies for marketing the produce...The original pilot nurseries have grown into Rural Resource Centres providing training in a wide range of skills as well as being the focal points for the diffusion of innovations. This has been an important step towards the wider dissemination of tree domestication. Now in 2009, the participatory tree domestication programme has become a part of a successful rural development programme which integrates tree domestication and agroforestry with other initiatives to help smallholder farmers to find pathways out of poverty and into more sustainable and enriched livelihoods. This is centred on village nurseries for the production of 'fertilizer' trees for soil improvement and newly domesticated cash crops developed from indigenous trees'
Study_goal: to fully capture the transformative nature of tree domestication to rural households' livelihoods, a more comprehensive study was carried out in 2008 to quantify and qualify a complex set of impacts in some pilot sites in Cameroon.'
Study_location: Centre and North-west regions
Stated_outcomes: Participation, motivation, household revenue, health and nutrition, human capital, social capital

Title: Participatory forest management in the Eastern Arc Mountains of Tanzania: who benefits?
Author_affil: CARE International in Tanzania, Uluguru Mountains Environmental Management and Conservation Project, P.O. Box 289, Morogoro, Tanzania
Funding: Global Environmental Facility through the United Nations Development Programme
Linked_refs: Socio-Economic Monitoring Programme (SEMP) of the CMEAMF projec
Stated_int: the Socio-economic Monitoring Programme (SEMP) of the Conservation and Management of Eastern Arc Mountain Forests (CMEAMF) project, Participatory forest management (PFM), Joint forest management (JFM), Community based forest management (CBFM)
Desired_out: PFM in Tanzania was envisaged to help deliver two broad policy outcomes: improved forest condition and improved people’s livelihoods (Blomley and Ramadhani 2006), in a manner congruent with the general national poverty reduction process (URT 2005).'
Study_goal: The paper summarises the results of research undertaken to assess the impact of PFM on different groups within communities in nine case study villages within or adjacent to the forests of Tanzania’s Eastern Arc Mountains (URT 2008). Part of a three-country study (see Schreckenberg and Luttrell, this issue), the work in Tanzania was undertaken through the Socio-economic Monitoring Programme (SEMP) of the Conservation and Management of Eastern Arc Mountain Forests (CMEAMF) project managed by CARE International in Tanzania and was guided by two research questions: 1. Can PFM contribute to livelihood and poverty reduction by providing rural people with a sustainable and equitably distributed stream of bene ts greater than those obtained under a non-PFM situation? 2. How do the impacts (both positive and negative) on poverty and equity of different forms of PFM compare?'
Study_location: Kiponzelo, Mswaha, Lulanzi, Mikwinini, Chanya, Kilama, Gombero, Mgambo, Mfyome - Eastern Arc Area
Stated_outcomes: Change in economic capital, physical capital, human capital, social and political capital, natural capital

Title: The Socio-economic Effect of the Reform of the Collective Forest Rights System in Southern China: A Case of Tonggu County, Jiangxi Province
Author_affil: Rural Development Institute, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, Beijing 100732, China
Funding: Innovation Project Fund of Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (Agricultural Resources and Rural Ecological Conservation)
Stated_int: Reform of the collective rights system (RCFRS)
Desired_out: Reform of the collective forest right system (RCFRS) is a major policy decided upon by the government to improve people’s living standards and the natural environment'
Study_goal: In this research, by means of multivariate analysis and a sustainable livelihood framework (SLF) (Fig. 1), survey data and data obtained by monitoring household lifestyles in both 2005 and 2012 have been analyzed to determine the program’s impacts. This paper covers the research into the following aspects of the RCFRS: Objective I: Analyze the changes in livelihood (means of making a living) and capital assets of income groups (high-income and low-income), and analyze the five livelihood and capital asset classes quantitatively, in the context of the SLF. Objective II: Analyze changes in the household livelihood strategies due to the program, and the various outcomes for the income groups.'
Study_location: Sanxi, Gaopi, Yangqing, Dacao, Shuangxi, Damei, and Yangfeng villages in Tonggu County, Jiangxi Province
Stated_outcomes: Change in household income and consumption, community scale financial capital, human capital, natural capital, physical capital, and social capital

Title: The implementation and impacts of China’s largest payment for ecosystem services program as revealed by longitudinal household data
Author_affil: College of Economics and Management, Northwest A&F University, Yangling 712100, China; Department of Forestry, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, USA
Funding: Northwest A&F University of China and the AgBioResearch of Michigan State University
Stated_int: Sloping Land Conversion Program (SLCP), afforestation, payments for ecosystem services (PES)
Desired_out: The environmental aspiration of the SLCP is to increase the country’s forest and grassland covers and thus reduce soil erosion, flooding, and desertification and other ecological disasters by primarily retiring and converting marginal, sloping lands from farming...Another goal of the program is to reduce poverty and promote rural development'
Study_goal: Using descriptive and econometric analyses based on a longitudinal dataset containing a large number of surveyed households over 1999–2008, we examine the multi-faceted changes in program enrollment, land and labor allocation, agricultural production, and income structure and inequality.'
Study_location: Nanbu, Nanjiang, Mabian, Muchuan counties (Sichuan Province) and Zhen'an and Yanchang counties (Shaanxi province)
Stated_outcomes: Participation, land/labor allocation, agricultural production, structural change in income, income inequality

Title: Impact of participatory forest management on financial assets of rural communities in Northwest Pakistan
Author_affil: Department of Agricultural Extension, University of Agriculture Faisalabad, Pakistan
Funding: Swiss National Centre of Competence in Research (NCCR) North–South: Research Partnerships for Mitigating Syndromes of Global Change.
Stated_int: Participatory forest management, village development committees, women organizations
Desired_out: The system of participatory forest management is in the stage of evolution in Pakistan. It was started in response to high rate of deforestation in the forest rich North West Frontier Province (NWFP) of Pakistan in 1996 through Asia Development Bank's funded forestry sector project (FSP). In the FSP model of participatory forest management the village development committees (VDC) and women organizations (WO) were established to manage the natural resources of the village, implement the village land use plan prepared in collaboration with the forest department, to monitor the physical and financial affairs of the village plan etc'
Study_goal: Is there any positive impact of participatory forest management in NWFP upon financial assets (cash income, access to loans and savings) and livelihood strategies of the local people and based on these insights, what policy implication can we suggest for the improvement of the system?
Study_location: Mansehra and Swat districts, Northwest Frontier Province
Stated_outcomes: sources of cash income, percent of cash income from forest resources, savings, access to loan
Portion_livelihood_amount: Primary (Project-3.5%,Non-project-0.5%), Secondary (Project-3.5%,Non-Project-2.5%)

Overall though all groups on average experienced decreases in livestock.

Title: Forests for Food Security and Livelihood Sustainability: Policy Problems and Opportunities for Small Farmers in Nepal
Author_affil: Faculty of Commerce, Lincoln University, Canterbury, New Zealand
Stated_int: Community forestry in Nepal: Reforestation of community pastureland and “reducing and controlling livestock numbers” to levels manageable with farm resources were considered to be solutions to the problem (Master Plan, 1988, p.148). The community forestry development program was implemented according to the policy guidelines (Edmonds, 2003; Hobley, 1996). In principle, community forestry transfers management responsibility to local communities, allowing them to make decisions appropriate to the community and to capture the benefits of their decisions. In practice afforestations occurred in community pasturelands. Livestock grazing and controlled forest collection were restricted (Dhakal et al., 2005; Bhatta 2000). The government also introduced the Forest Amendment Act in 1998 and a mandatory forest inventory introduced to regulate forest uses and contribute to global environmental conservation, including global climate change mitigation as directed by “Sustainable Forestry” in Agenda 21. The policy has dictated compulsory forest inventories and limited forest harvesting to less than 30% of mean annual increment (MAI) for slow growing species and 60% of MAI for fast growing species1
Desired_out: Environmental protection, sustainable use of forest resources
Study_goal: The purpose of this study is to...develop a model of community welfare maximization that incorporates common property resource allocation decisions and different policy constraints on forest use and household livestock holdings.
Study_location: Six CFUGs in the Dolakha, Kavre and Nuwakot districts of the mid-hill region of Nepal
Stated_outcomes: Change in livestock numbers by household after community forestry introduction is based on data; rest of paper is a theoretical modeling exercise
Stated_mech: Overall, livestock provide a hedge against starvation and extreme poverty, particularly for isolated mountain communities (Riethmuller, 2003). Public forests have special importance for livestock farming and livelihoods for mountain people in Nepal. Historically, land areas demanding less labor for terracing and suitable for crop production were privatized. Less productive and environmentally sensitive lands were managed as public or communal property for production of multiple products and services (firewood, fodder, pasture, timber, leaf litter, and other non-timber products). As a result, almost all Nepali farmers have no private pastureland. Instead, the farmers graze livestock in forests, or tree limbs are lopped during seasons of animal feed deficits

Title: The Link Between Community Forestry Policies and Poverty and Unemployment in Rural Nepal
Author_affil: Lincoln University, Commerce Division, PO Box 84, 7647 Lincoln, Canterbury, New Zealand
Funding: Winrock-Nepal and Lincoln University, New Zealand
Linked_refs: Same data/results as Dhakal et al 2010
Stated_int: Current government forest policy: Current government policy dictates the use of all community forestland for environmental conservation and limited timber production, and provides little scope for fodder and firewood production. Community forestry in Nepal established 13,000 forest user groups to manage community forestland.
Desired_out: Environmental conservation; sustainable forest use; empowerment of local communities
Study_goal: The present article examines the relationship between community forest management policies on the one hand, and income and unemployment in rural areas of Nepal on the other, by modeling the effect of forest management constraints on community forest use.
Study_location: 3 districts (Dolakha, Kavre, and Nuwakot) of the mid-hill region of Nepal
Stated_outcomes: Household income under current policy
Stated_mech: However, despite the establishment of more than 13,000 forest user groups, the impact of the community forestry program on reducing rural poverty and unemployment is debatable (Dhakal 2005). There have been improvements in physical forest resources and the environment, and flows of community development funds from sales of forest products (Dongol et al 2002; Gautam et al 2002; Dhakal 2005). However, parallel with this, there has been a reduction in fodder and firewood supplies (Malla 2000; Dhakal et al 2005), and household income, employment, and livestock holdings have decreased (Bhatta 2002; Timilsina 2003). Since wealthier households have sufficient private landholdings to produce their own fodder, the effects of these reductions appear to have been disproportionately felt by the poorest households, women, and minorities (Agrawal 2001; Adhikari et al 2004; Dhakal 2006; Maskey et al 2006).

Title: Community participation in a social forestry program in Central Java, Indonesia: the effect of incentive structure and social capital
Author_affil: Laboratory of Agricultural History, Department of Agricultural and Resource Economics, Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences, The University of Tokyo, 1-1-1 Yayoi, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8657, Japan
Funding: This work was supported by Japan Society for the Promotion of Science and Directorate General of Higher Education Core University Program in Applied Biosciences.
Stated_int: Social forestry program: A new social forestry program has been implemented in Java to overcome encroachment of state forests. In this program, the state and local communities jointly manage the state forests and share the benefits of increased forest resource stock and flow as a result of the management. Tumpang sari (TS), a temporal type of agroforestry, is a conventional way to provide such incentive.In TS, a parcel of state forestland is allocated to a farm household where members of that household plant teak trees and maintain the young trees for 2 years. TS attracts small or landless farmers in need of cultivation land who are dependent on forest resources for their livelihoods. In exchange for labor contributed toward planting and maintaining the trees, TS farmers receive a small cash payment and can keep all yields from intercropping of food crops such as maize (Zea mays indentata), peanut (Arachis hypogaea L.), and cassava (Manihot esculenta). After 2 years, the farmers have to leave their TS parcel and can cultivate in a new parcel. A new social forestry program in the Gunung Kidul District namely Hutan Kemasyarakatan (HKM) was formulated in 2001 and established in 2002. Unlike in the conventional TS where food crop cultivation was allowed only for 2 years, in the HKM TS farmers were allowed to cultivate a parcel in state forestland for 25 years. They would plant their parcels with teak trees, maintain them, and share the timber with the state. Long-term usufruct rights for farming activities on state forestland and timber sharing are the new arrangements introduced in the HKM.
Desired_out: To reduce encroachment in state forests
Study_goal: This article aims to investigate the complete incentive structure of the social forestry program and how the incentive structure changes community member participation in forest management. Property rights transfers and economic analyses were employed to analyze the incentive structure.This article examines the new social forestry program implemented in state forestlands in the Gunung Kidul District that is under the management of the FD. It is the only state forestland under FD management where the new social forestry program has been implemented.
Study_location: State forestlands in the Gunung Kidul District, Java
Study_duration: Data are from field research in 2003, 2004, 2005, and 2007
Stated_outcomes: HKM member benefit–cost ratio and internal rate of return of teak growing
